{"lassa fevernum_articles": "354", "lassa fever": [{"archive_id": "8216492", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - West Africa (04): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8216492", "date": "2020-07-04 20:54:35", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (21): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 28 Jun 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever [LF] situation report -- epidemiological week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020)\n------------------------------\n\nKey points\n------------\nCurrent week (26) (22-28 Jun 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-26 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-26\nSuspected cases: 67 / 5201 / 2882\nConfirmed cases: 4 / 1040 / 603\nProbable cases: 0 / 14 / 17\nDeaths: 2 / 218 / 136\nCase fatality rate (CFR [%]): 50.0 / 21.0 / 22.6\nNumber of states affected: 2 / 27 / 22\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 3 / 129 / 83\n\nHighlights\n- In week 26, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 5 in week 25, 2020, to 4 cases. These were reported from 4 states (Ondo, Edo, Taraba, and Plateau) (Table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 25, 2020, 216 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 20.8%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.5%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 129 local government areas (Figure 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 72% are from Ondo (33%), Edo (32%), and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age-group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (Figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- No new healthcare worker was affected in the reporting week 26.\n- Lassa fever outbreak emergency phase declared over on 28 Apr 2020 based on composite indicators national threshold.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG), continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure [graph] 1. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (25), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The national multisectoral Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) was activated to coordinate response activities across states. States with confirmed cases have activated state- level EOCs.\n- National Rapid Response Teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 10 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratorians, and hygienist) deployed to ISTH and FMC Owo\n- State Public Health Emergency Operations Centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 Lassa fever molecular laboratories in the NCDC network are working full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time.\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC commodities.\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies.\n- Implementation of Lassa fever environmental response campaign in high-burden states by Federal Ministry of Environment\n\nNotes on this report\nData source\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre.\n\nCase definitions\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either a. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, b. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever\n\nCalculations\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 4 new confirmed and 67 new suspected cases in week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing but declining considerably. The decline is doubtless responsible for the declaration of the end of the emergency phase of the disease on 28 Apr 2020. The graph in Figure 6 indicates that a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. There are now 218 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). Fortunately, there are no newly infected healthcare workers during the current week (week 26).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo, Ebonyi, and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, and local government areas remain at 129 with at least one case. Nigeria is into the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March 2020) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this is the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis;\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/.\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (01): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8064129", "date": "2020-07-04 20:54:35", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (21): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 28 Jun 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever [LF] situation report -- epidemiological week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020)\n------------------------------\n\nKey points\n------------\nCurrent week (26) (22-28 Jun 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-26 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-26\nSuspected cases: 67 / 5201 / 2882\nConfirmed cases: 4 / 1040 / 603\nProbable cases: 0 / 14 / 17\nDeaths: 2 / 218 / 136\nCase fatality rate (CFR [%]): 50.0 / 21.0 / 22.6\nNumber of states affected: 2 / 27 / 22\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 3 / 129 / 83\n\nHighlights\n- In week 26, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 5 in week 25, 2020, to 4 cases. These were reported from 4 states (Ondo, Edo, Taraba, and Plateau) (Table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 25, 2020, 216 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 20.8%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.5%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 129 local government areas (Figure 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 72% are from Ondo (33%), Edo (32%), and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age-group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (Figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- No new healthcare worker was affected in the reporting week 26.\n- Lassa fever outbreak emergency phase declared over on 28 Apr 2020 based on composite indicators national threshold.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG), continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure [graph] 1. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (25), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The national multisectoral Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) was activated to coordinate response activities across states. States with confirmed cases have activated state- level EOCs.\n- National Rapid Response Teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 10 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratorians, and hygienist) deployed to ISTH and FMC Owo\n- State Public Health Emergency Operations Centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 Lassa fever molecular laboratories in the NCDC network are working full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time.\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC commodities.\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies.\n- Implementation of Lassa fever environmental response campaign in high-burden states by Federal Ministry of Environment\n\nNotes on this report\nData source\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre.\n\nCase definitions\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either a. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, b. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever\n\nCalculations\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 4 new confirmed and 67 new suspected cases in week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing but declining considerably. The decline is doubtless responsible for the declaration of the end of the emergency phase of the disease on 28 Apr 2020. The graph in Figure 6 indicates that a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. There are now 218 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). Fortunately, there are no newly infected healthcare workers during the current week (week 26).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo, Ebonyi, and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, and local government areas remain at 129 with at least one case. Nigeria is into the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March 2020) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this is the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis;\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/.\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (22): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7716240", "date": "2020-07-04 20:54:35", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (21): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 28 Jun 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever [LF] situation report -- epidemiological week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020)\n------------------------------\n\nKey points\n------------\nCurrent week (26) (22-28 Jun 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-26 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-26\nSuspected cases: 67 / 5201 / 2882\nConfirmed cases: 4 / 1040 / 603\nProbable cases: 0 / 14 / 17\nDeaths: 2 / 218 / 136\nCase fatality rate (CFR [%]): 50.0 / 21.0 / 22.6\nNumber of states affected: 2 / 27 / 22\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 3 / 129 / 83\n\nHighlights\n- In week 26, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 5 in week 25, 2020, to 4 cases. These were reported from 4 states (Ondo, Edo, Taraba, and Plateau) (Table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 25, 2020, 216 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 20.8%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.5%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 129 local government areas (Figure 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 72% are from Ondo (33%), Edo (32%), and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age-group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (Figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- No new healthcare worker was affected in the reporting week 26.\n- Lassa fever outbreak emergency phase declared over on 28 Apr 2020 based on composite indicators national threshold.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG), continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure [graph] 1. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-26, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-26, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (25), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The national multisectoral Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) was activated to coordinate response activities across states. States with confirmed cases have activated state- level EOCs.\n- National Rapid Response Teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 10 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratorians, and hygienist) deployed to ISTH and FMC Owo\n- State Public Health Emergency Operations Centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 Lassa fever molecular laboratories in the NCDC network are working full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time.\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC commodities.\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies.\n- Implementation of Lassa fever environmental response campaign in high-burden states by Federal Ministry of Environment\n\nNotes on this report\nData source\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre.\n\nCase definitions\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either a. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, b. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever\n\nCalculations\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 4 new confirmed and 67 new suspected cases in week 26 (22-28 Jun 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing but declining considerably. The decline is doubtless responsible for the declaration of the end of the emergency phase of the disease on 28 Apr 2020. The graph in Figure 6 indicates that a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. There are now 218 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). Fortunately, there are no newly infected healthcare workers during the current week (week 26).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo, Ebonyi, and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, and local government areas remain at 129 with at least one case. Nigeria is into the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March 2020) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this is the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis;\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/.\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (20): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7503129", "date": "2020-03-05 18:02:09", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (13): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever situation report -- epidemiological week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020)\n-------------------------------------\nKey points\n----------\nTable 1: Summary of current week (9), cumulative from epiweeks 1-9, 2020, and comparison with previous year (2019).\nCurrent week (9) [(24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-9 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-9\nSuspected cases: 421 / 3054 / 1374\nConfirmed cases: 85 / 775 / 420\nProbable cases: 0 / 9 / 15\nDeaths: 11 / 132 / 93\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.9% / 17.0% / 22.1%\nNumber of states affected: 9 / 27 / 21\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 30 / 118 / 66\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 9, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 102 cases in week 8, 2020, to 85 cases. These were reported from 9 states (Edo, Ondo, Ebonyi, Bauchi, Plateau, Benue, Kogi, Taraba, and Kebbi) (table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 9, 2020, 132 deaths have been reported with a CFR of 17.0%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.1%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 118 local government areas [LGAs] (figures 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 73% are from Edo (34%), Ondo (32%) and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 [year] to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared with that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- One new healthcare worker was affected in Edo state in the reporting week 9.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure 1 [graph]. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1 to 9, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (9), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The National Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) has been activated to coordinate response activities across states. Of the states with confirmed cases, 8 of them have activated state-level EOCs.\n- National rapid response teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 9 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, hygienists) deployed to Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital [ISTH; in Edo State] and Federal Medical Center [FMC] Owo [in Ondo State]\n- State public health emergency operations centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 molecular laboratories for Lassa fever testing in the NCDC network are working at full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC [infection prevention and control] commodities\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies\n\nNotes on this report\n--------------------\nData source\n-----------\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever EOC.\n\nCase definitions\n----------------\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and has either a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or b) history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation).\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing.\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever.\n- Healthcare worker (HCW) infections may not necessarily be of nosocomial origin; proposed study to differentiate nosocomial healthcare worker infection from community infection.\n\nCalculations\n------------\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 85 new confirmed and 421 new suspected cases in week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing at a relatively high level, although declining somewhat. The graph in Figure 6 indicates a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. It will be interesting to see if the decline in cases continues going forward. There are now 132 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). There is one new infected healthcare worker during the current week (week 9).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, but local government areas increased to 118 with at least one case. Nigeria is still into the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (Jan-Mar) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. West Africa (19): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7412415", "date": "2020-03-05 18:02:09", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (13): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever situation report -- epidemiological week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020)\n-------------------------------------\nKey points\n----------\nTable 1: Summary of current week (9), cumulative from epiweeks 1-9, 2020, and comparison with previous year (2019).\nCurrent week (9) [(24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-9 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-9\nSuspected cases: 421 / 3054 / 1374\nConfirmed cases: 85 / 775 / 420\nProbable cases: 0 / 9 / 15\nDeaths: 11 / 132 / 93\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.9% / 17.0% / 22.1%\nNumber of states affected: 9 / 27 / 21\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 30 / 118 / 66\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 9, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 102 cases in week 8, 2020, to 85 cases. These were reported from 9 states (Edo, Ondo, Ebonyi, Bauchi, Plateau, Benue, Kogi, Taraba, and Kebbi) (table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 9, 2020, 132 deaths have been reported with a CFR of 17.0%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.1%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 118 local government areas [LGAs] (figures 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 73% are from Edo (34%), Ondo (32%) and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 [year] to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared with that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- One new healthcare worker was affected in Edo state in the reporting week 9.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure 1 [graph]. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1 to 9, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (9), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The National Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) has been activated to coordinate response activities across states. Of the states with confirmed cases, 8 of them have activated state-level EOCs.\n- National rapid response teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 9 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, hygienists) deployed to Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital [ISTH; in Edo State] and Federal Medical Center [FMC] Owo [in Ondo State]\n- State public health emergency operations centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 molecular laboratories for Lassa fever testing in the NCDC network are working at full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC [infection prevention and control] commodities\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies\n\nNotes on this report\n--------------------\nData source\n-----------\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever EOC.\n\nCase definitions\n----------------\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and has either a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or b) history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation).\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing.\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever.\n- Healthcare worker (HCW) infections may not necessarily be of nosocomial origin; proposed study to differentiate nosocomial healthcare worker infection from community infection.\n\nCalculations\n------------\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 85 new confirmed and 421 new suspected cases in week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing at a relatively high level, although declining somewhat. The graph in Figure 6 indicates a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. It will be interesting to see if the decline in cases continues going forward. There are now 132 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). There is one new infected healthcare worker during the current week (week 9).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, but local government areas increased to 118 with at least one case. Nigeria is still into the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (Jan-Mar) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (16): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7216572", "date": "2020-03-05 18:02:09", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (13): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever situation report -- epidemiological week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020)\n-------------------------------------\nKey points\n----------\nTable 1: Summary of current week (9), cumulative from epiweeks 1-9, 2020, and comparison with previous year (2019).\nCurrent week (9) [(24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-9 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-9\nSuspected cases: 421 / 3054 / 1374\nConfirmed cases: 85 / 775 / 420\nProbable cases: 0 / 9 / 15\nDeaths: 11 / 132 / 93\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.9% / 17.0% / 22.1%\nNumber of states affected: 9 / 27 / 21\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 30 / 118 / 66\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 9, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 102 cases in week 8, 2020, to 85 cases. These were reported from 9 states (Edo, Ondo, Ebonyi, Bauchi, Plateau, Benue, Kogi, Taraba, and Kebbi) (table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 9, 2020, 132 deaths have been reported with a CFR of 17.0%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.1%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 118 local government areas [LGAs] (figures 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 73% are from Edo (34%), Ondo (32%) and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 [year] to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared with that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- One new healthcare worker was affected in Edo state in the reporting week 9.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure 1 [graph]. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1 to 9, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (9), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The National Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) has been activated to coordinate response activities across states. Of the states with confirmed cases, 8 of them have activated state-level EOCs.\n- National rapid response teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 9 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, hygienists) deployed to Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital [ISTH; in Edo State] and Federal Medical Center [FMC] Owo [in Ondo State]\n- State public health emergency operations centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 molecular laboratories for Lassa fever testing in the NCDC network are working at full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC [infection prevention and control] commodities\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies\n\nNotes on this report\n--------------------\nData source\n-----------\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever EOC.\n\nCase definitions\n----------------\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and has either a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or b) history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation).\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing.\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever.\n- Healthcare worker (HCW) infections may not necessarily be of nosocomial origin; proposed study to differentiate nosocomial healthcare worker infection from community infection.\n\nCalculations\n------------\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 85 new confirmed and 421 new suspected cases in week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing at a relatively high level, although declining somewhat. The graph in Figure 6 indicates a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. It will be interesting to see if the decline in cases continues going forward. There are now 132 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). There is one new infected healthcare worker during the current week (week 9).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, but local government areas increased to 118 with at least one case. Nigeria is still into the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (Jan-Mar) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (13): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7054665", "date": "2020-03-05 18:02:09", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (13): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Mar 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nLassa fever situation report -- epidemiological week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020)\n-------------------------------------\nKey points\n----------\nTable 1: Summary of current week (9), cumulative from epiweeks 1-9, 2020, and comparison with previous year (2019).\nCurrent week (9) [(24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) / Cumulative weeks 1-9 / Cumulative 2019 weeks 1-9\nSuspected cases: 421 / 3054 / 1374\nConfirmed cases: 85 / 775 / 420\nProbable cases: 0 / 9 / 15\nDeaths: 11 / 132 / 93\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.9% / 17.0% / 22.1%\nNumber of states affected: 9 / 27 / 21\nLocal government areas (LGAs) affected: 30 / 118 / 66\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 9, the number of new confirmed cases decreased from 102 cases in week 8, 2020, to 85 cases. These were reported from 9 states (Edo, Ondo, Ebonyi, Bauchi, Plateau, Benue, Kogi, Taraba, and Kebbi) (table 3).\n- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 9, 2020, 132 deaths have been reported with a CFR of 17.0%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2019 (22.1%).\n- In total for 2020, 27 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 118 local government areas [LGAs] (figures 2 and 3).\n- Of all confirmed cases, 73% are from Edo (34%), Ondo (32%) and Ebonyi (7%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (range: less than 1 [year] to 78 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.2 (figure 4).\n- The number of suspected cases has significantly increased compared with that reported for the same period in 2019.\n- One new healthcare worker was affected in Edo state in the reporting week 9.\n\n[The following are available at the source URL above:]\nFigure 1 [graph]. Epidemic curve of confirmed Lassa fever cases from epidemiological week 1 to 9, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 1-9, 2020\nTable 2: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nTable 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2020\nFigure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 1-9, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020 (9), Nigeria\n\nResponse activities\n- The National Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) has been activated to coordinate response activities across states. Of the states with confirmed cases, 8 of them have activated state-level EOCs.\n- National rapid response teams have been deployed from NCDC to support response activities in 9 states.\n- Surge staff (doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, hygienists) deployed to Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital [ISTH; in Edo State] and Federal Medical Center [FMC] Owo [in Ondo State]\n- State public health emergency operations centre activated in affected states\n- The 5 molecular laboratories for Lassa fever testing in the NCDC network are working at full capacity to ensure that all samples are tested and results provided within the shortest turnaround time\n- NCDC is working to support every state in Nigeria to identify one treatment centre, while supporting existing ones with care, treatment, and IPC [infection prevention and control] commodities\n- Risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies\n\nNotes on this report\n--------------------\nData source\n-----------\nInformation for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever EOC.\n\nCase definitions\n----------------\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and has either a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or b) history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, OR any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation).\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing.\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever.\n- Healthcare worker (HCW) infections may not necessarily be of nosocomial origin; proposed study to differentiate nosocomial healthcare worker infection from community infection.\n\nCalculations\n------------\n- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 85 new confirmed and 421 new suspected cases in week 9 (24 Feb-1 Mar 2020) indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing at a relatively high level, although declining somewhat. The graph in Figure 6 indicates a peak of cases may have occurred in week 7. It will be interesting to see if the decline in cases continues going forward. There are now 132 deaths among confirmed cases so far this year (2020). There is one new infected healthcare worker during the current week (week 9).\n\nThe report above confirms that Ondo and Edo states have the majority of cases. The area affected remains at 27 states, but local government areas increased to 118 with at least one case. Nigeria is still into the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (available at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (Jan-Mar) over the past 3 years, and it appears that this will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - The state chief epidemiologist, Dr Steven Fagbemi, disclosed this on Tuesday [21 Jan 2020] at the governor's office in the Government House in Akure, the state capital.\n\nDr Fagbemi made the disclosure while briefing Governor Oluwarotimi Akeredolu as well as the local government chairmen from Ondo North and Central senatorial districts of the state. He also revealed that 84 cases have been reported so far in the state since 1 Jan 2020.\n\nAccording to the epidemiologist, 16 of the patients have passed on, as their cases had reached the advanced stage before they were taken to the hospital. He added that 47 patients on admission were responding to treatment, while 21 others had already been treated and discharged.\n\nThe outbreak is said to have affected Owo, Akoko South-West, Akure South, and Ondo West LGAs of the state.\n\nAlso confirming the outbreak, the commissioner for health, Dr Wahab Adegbenro, noted that the disease has been occurring in the state for some years, especially during the dry season. He therefore advised Nigerians to visit hospitals when they noticed symptoms of fever.\n\nEarlier, Governor Akeredolu advised the local government chairmen in the state to deploy cleaners to markets and public places to prevent the outbreak of diseases. He also called on residents to maintain a high level of hygiene to curtail further spread of the Lassa virus in the state.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 81 new confirmed and 159 suspected cases in week 3 of 2020 indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing to accelerate. The 1st report above confirms that Ondo state has the majority of cases, tied with Edo state. Nigeria is now entering the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\nThe pygmy mouse (_Mus baoulei_) has recently been implicated as a reservoir species in West Africa but not in Nigeria.\n\nThere is no specific mention in the plans above of public education for avoidance of contact with these rodents and their excreta. - West Africa (10): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6987321", "date": "2020-01-23 17:28:33", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (05): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Official update\n[2] Ondo state\n\n******\n[1] Official update\nDate: Sun 19 Jan 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control Lassa fever situation report [edited]\nhttps://www.ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nEpi week 3, 13-19 Jan 2020\n\nKey points\n\nTable 1: Summary of current week indicators [for week 3]\nSuspected cases (negative): 159 (78)\nConfirmed cases: 81\nDeaths: 10\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.3%\nNumber of states affected: 6\nLGAs affected: 17\n\nTable 2: Cumulative data compared to previous year (week 1 - current week) [for 2019 and 2020]\nSuspected cases (negative)\n- 2019: 379 (237)\n- 2020: 398 (235)\nConfirmed cases\n- 2019: 141\n- 2020: 163\nDeaths for confirmed cases\n- 2019: 33\n- 2020: 24\nCFR%\n- 2019: 23.4%\n- 2020: 14.7%\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 3, the number of new confirmed cases has increased from 64 cases in week 1, 2020, to 81. These [new cases] were reported from 6 states (Ondo, Edo, Delta, Taraba, Plateau, and Bauchi) (Table 3).\n- The number of deaths has decreased. The overall CFR for 2020 is (14.7%), which is lower than the CFR for the same period during 2019 (23.4%) (Figure 5).\n- In total for 2020, 9 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 32 local government areas [LGAs].\n- 89% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (38%), Ondo (38%), and Ebonyi (11%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 11-40 years (range: greater than 11 to 60 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1 (Figure 3).\n- The number of suspected cases has increased but is lower than the numbers reported in 2019.\n- No healthcare-worker infection was identified in the reporting week 3.\n\nFigures and tables [available at the source URL above]\nFigure 1 [graph]: Epidemic curve showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases by epidemiological week 48, 2019, to week 3, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever cases in LGAs in Nigeria, cumulative 2020 to current week\nFigure 3 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 3, 2020\nFigure 4 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-3, 2020\nTable 3: Confirmed cases by state, current week 2020 with trend compared to previous week\nTable 4: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nFigure 4 [graph]: Age and sex pyramid of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with CFR by state, week 1-3, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020, Nigeria\nTable 5: Response activities\n\nChallenges\n- Sustainability of Lassa fever outbreak response by states\n- Poor environmental sanitation conditions observed in high-burden communities\n- Poor risk communication activities at the state level leading to late presentation of cases\n- Poor IPC institutionalisation at state level and treatment centres\n- Implementation of rodent control measures in hotspot LGAs - phase 2\n\nNotes on this report\nData source\n- Information for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the Technical Working Group.\n\nCase definitions\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either\na. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or\nb. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, or any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR or virus isolation)\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever\n- Active state: means where there has been at least one confirmed case, and contacts within 21 days post-exposure\n- CFR for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ondo state\nDate: Tue 21 Jan 2020\nSource: Channels TV [edited]\nhttps://www.channelstv.com/2020/01/21/lassa-fever-kills-16-people-in-ondo/\n\n\nIn Ondo state, 16 people have been confirmed killed as a result of a Lassa fever outbreak. The state chief epidemiologist, Dr Steven Fagbemi, disclosed this on Tuesday [21 Jan 2020] at the governor's office in the Government House in Akure, the state capital.\n\nDr Fagbemi made the disclosure while briefing Governor Oluwarotimi Akeredolu as well as the local government chairmen from Ondo North and Central senatorial districts of the state. He also revealed that 84 cases have been reported so far in the state since 1 Jan 2020.\n\nAccording to the epidemiologist, 16 of the patients have passed on, as their cases had reached the advanced stage before they were taken to the hospital. He added that 47 patients on admission were responding to treatment, while 21 others had already been treated and discharged.\n\nThe outbreak is said to have affected Owo, Akoko South-West, Akure South, and Ondo West LGAs of the state.\n\nAlso confirming the outbreak, the commissioner for health, Dr Wahab Adegbenro, noted that the disease has been occurring in the state for some years, especially during the dry season. He therefore advised Nigerians to visit hospitals when they noticed symptoms of fever.\n\nEarlier, Governor Akeredolu advised the local government chairmen in the state to deploy cleaners to markets and public places to prevent the outbreak of diseases. He also called on residents to maintain a high level of hygiene to curtail further spread of the Lassa virus in the state.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 81 new confirmed and 159 suspected cases in week 3 of 2020 indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing to accelerate. The 1st report above confirms that Ondo state has the majority of cases, tied with Edo state. Nigeria is now entering the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\nThe pygmy mouse (_Mus baoulei_) has recently been implicated as a reservoir species in West Africa but not in Nigeria.\n\nThere is no specific mention in the plans above of public education for avoidance of contact with these rodents and their excreta. - West Africa (07): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6930926", "date": "2020-01-23 17:28:33", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (05): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Official update\n[2] Ondo state\n\n******\n[1] Official update\nDate: Sun 19 Jan 2020\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control Lassa fever situation report [edited]\nhttps://www.ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nEpi week 3, 13-19 Jan 2020\n\nKey points\n\nTable 1: Summary of current week indicators [for week 3]\nSuspected cases (negative): 159 (78)\nConfirmed cases: 81\nDeaths: 10\nCase fatality rate (CFR): 12.3%\nNumber of states affected: 6\nLGAs affected: 17\n\nTable 2: Cumulative data compared to previous year (week 1 - current week) [for 2019 and 2020]\nSuspected cases (negative)\n- 2019: 379 (237)\n- 2020: 398 (235)\nConfirmed cases\n- 2019: 141\n- 2020: 163\nDeaths for confirmed cases\n- 2019: 33\n- 2020: 24\nCFR%\n- 2019: 23.4%\n- 2020: 14.7%\n\nHighlights\n\n- In week 3, the number of new confirmed cases has increased from 64 cases in week 1, 2020, to 81. These [new cases] were reported from 6 states (Ondo, Edo, Delta, Taraba, Plateau, and Bauchi) (Table 3).\n- The number of deaths has decreased. The overall CFR for 2020 is (14.7%), which is lower than the CFR for the same period during 2019 (23.4%) (Figure 5).\n- In total for 2020, 9 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 32 local government areas [LGAs].\n- 89% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (38%), Ondo (38%), and Ebonyi (11%) states.\n- The predominant age group affected is 11-40 years (range: greater than 11 to 60 years; median age: 33 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1 (Figure 3).\n- The number of suspected cases has increased but is lower than the numbers reported in 2019.\n- No healthcare-worker infection was identified in the reporting week 3.\n\nFigures and tables [available at the source URL above]\nFigure 1 [graph]: Epidemic curve showing number of confirmed Lassa fever cases by epidemiological week 48, 2019, to week 3, 2020\nFigure 2 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever cases in LGAs in Nigeria, cumulative 2020 to current week\nFigure 3 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 3, 2020\nFigure 4 [map]: Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 1-3, 2020\nTable 3: Confirmed cases by state, current week 2020 with trend compared to previous week\nTable 4: Key indicators for current week 2020 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria\nFigure 4 [graph]: Age and sex pyramid of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2020\nFigure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with CFR by state, week 1-3, 2020\nFigure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2016-2020, Nigeria\nTable 5: Response activities\n\nChallenges\n- Sustainability of Lassa fever outbreak response by states\n- Poor environmental sanitation conditions observed in high-burden communities\n- Poor risk communication activities at the state level leading to late presentation of cases\n- Poor IPC institutionalisation at state level and treatment centres\n- Implementation of rodent control measures in hotspot LGAs - phase 2\n\nNotes on this report\nData source\n- Information for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the Technical Working Group.\n\nCase definitions\n- Suspected case: any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either\na. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents, or\nb. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, or any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n- Confirmed case: any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR or virus isolation)\n- Probable case: any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of a specimen for laboratory testing\n- Contact: anyone who has been exposed to an infected person or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever\n- Active state: means where there has been at least one confirmed case, and contacts within 21 days post-exposure\n- CFR for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ondo state\nDate: Tue 21 Jan 2020\nSource: Channels TV [edited]\nhttps://www.channelstv.com/2020/01/21/lassa-fever-kills-16-people-in-ondo/\n\n\nIn Ondo state, 16 people have been confirmed killed as a result of a Lassa fever outbreak. The state chief epidemiologist, Dr Steven Fagbemi, disclosed this on Tuesday [21 Jan 2020] at the governor's office in the Government House in Akure, the state capital.\n\nDr Fagbemi made the disclosure while briefing Governor Oluwarotimi Akeredolu as well as the local government chairmen from Ondo North and Central senatorial districts of the state. He also revealed that 84 cases have been reported so far in the state since 1 Jan 2020.\n\nAccording to the epidemiologist, 16 of the patients have passed on, as their cases had reached the advanced stage before they were taken to the hospital. He added that 47 patients on admission were responding to treatment, while 21 others had already been treated and discharged.\n\nThe outbreak is said to have affected Owo, Akoko South-West, Akure South, and Ondo West LGAs of the state.\n\nAlso confirming the outbreak, the commissioner for health, Dr Wahab Adegbenro, noted that the disease has been occurring in the state for some years, especially during the dry season. He therefore advised Nigerians to visit hospitals when they noticed symptoms of fever.\n\nEarlier, Governor Akeredolu advised the local government chairmen in the state to deploy cleaners to markets and public places to prevent the outbreak of diseases. He also called on residents to maintain a high level of hygiene to curtail further spread of the Lassa virus in the state.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 81 new confirmed and 159 suspected cases in week 3 of 2020 indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing to accelerate. The 1st report above confirms that Ondo state has the majority of cases, tied with Edo state. Nigeria is now entering the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 6 (at the source URL above). There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2020).\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\nThe pygmy mouse (_Mus baoulei_) has recently been implicated as a reservoir species in West Africa but not in Nigeria.\n\nThere is no specific mention in the plans above of public education for avoidance of contact with these rodents and their excreta. - West Africa (04): Liberia (GB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6901139", "date": "2019-12-05 20:03:25", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (42): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2019\nSource: Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/69c3c32b820f509b646a7c37fb02e508.pdf\n\n\nHighlights\n\n- In the reporting week 47 (18-24 Nov 2019), 8 new confirmed** cases were reported from Ondo (5) and Edo (3) states with no new deaths.\n- From 1 Jan-24 Nov 2019, a total of 4681 suspected* cases have been reported from 23 states. Of these, 785 were confirmed positive, 19 were probable, and 3877 were negative (not a case).\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 160 deaths in confirmed cases. Case-fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 20.4%.\n- A total of 23 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi, Cross River, Zamfara, Lagos, and Abia) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 86 local government areas [LGAs] (Figure 1).\n- 93% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (38%), Ondo (32%), Ebonyi (7%), Bauchi (7%), Taraba (5%), and Plateau (5%) states (Figure 1).\n- Predominant age group affected is 21-40 years (range: greater than one month to 98 years; median age: 34 years) (Figure 6).\n- The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1 (Figure 6).\n- In the reporting week 47, no new healthcare worker was affected. A total of 19 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 10 states: Edo (6), Ondo (4), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Delta (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states.\n- A total of 20 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment centre (9), Federal Medical Centre, Owo (9), and Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (1).\n- A total of 9321 contacts have been identified from 21 states. Of these, 347 (3.7%) are currently being followed up, 8894 (95.4%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 12 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. 144 symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 68 (47.2%) have tested positive.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate response activities at all levels.\n\nFigures [available at the source URL above]\n-------------------------------------------\nFigure 1 [map]. Randomised distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 2 [map]. LGAs with confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed cases (754) in Nigeria, week 1-47, 2019.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, week 1, 2016-week 47, 2019.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case-fatality rates (CFR) as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\n\n*Suspected case describes any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either (a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents or (b) history of contact with a probably or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, or any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n**Any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 8 new confirmed and 4681 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria should be in the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3 (at the source URL above), but more cases are still occurring. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again next year (2020).\n\nThe number of confirmed deaths has remained the same, 158. Fortunately, there are also no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 19, a likely indication that effective barrier nursing and the use of personal protective equipment are being employed. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 23 states, and the number of affected LGAs remains at 86. ProMED-mail readers may wish to see the maps and graphs (Figures 1-6) that are available at the source URL above.\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThere is no mention in the plans above of public education for avoidance of contact with these rodents and their excreta. - West Africa (01): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6865640", "date": "2019-12-05 20:03:25", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (42): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2019\nSource: Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/69c3c32b820f509b646a7c37fb02e508.pdf\n\n\nHighlights\n\n- In the reporting week 47 (18-24 Nov 2019), 8 new confirmed** cases were reported from Ondo (5) and Edo (3) states with no new deaths.\n- From 1 Jan-24 Nov 2019, a total of 4681 suspected* cases have been reported from 23 states. Of these, 785 were confirmed positive, 19 were probable, and 3877 were negative (not a case).\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 160 deaths in confirmed cases. Case-fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 20.4%.\n- A total of 23 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi, Cross River, Zamfara, Lagos, and Abia) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 86 local government areas [LGAs] (Figure 1).\n- 93% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (38%), Ondo (32%), Ebonyi (7%), Bauchi (7%), Taraba (5%), and Plateau (5%) states (Figure 1).\n- Predominant age group affected is 21-40 years (range: greater than one month to 98 years; median age: 34 years) (Figure 6).\n- The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1 (Figure 6).\n- In the reporting week 47, no new healthcare worker was affected. A total of 19 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 10 states: Edo (6), Ondo (4), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Delta (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states.\n- A total of 20 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment centre (9), Federal Medical Centre, Owo (9), and Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (1).\n- A total of 9321 contacts have been identified from 21 states. Of these, 347 (3.7%) are currently being followed up, 8894 (95.4%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 12 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. 144 symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 68 (47.2%) have tested positive.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate response activities at all levels.\n\nFigures [available at the source URL above]\n-------------------------------------------\nFigure 1 [map]. Randomised distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 2 [map]. LGAs with confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed cases (754) in Nigeria, week 1-47, 2019.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, week 1, 2016-week 47, 2019.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case-fatality rates (CFR) as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\n\n*Suspected case describes any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either (a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents or (b) history of contact with a probably or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, or any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n**Any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 8 new confirmed and 4681 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria should be in the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3 (at the source URL above), but more cases are still occurring. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again next year (2020).\n\nThe number of confirmed deaths has remained the same, 158. Fortunately, there are also no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 19, a likely indication that effective barrier nursing and the use of personal protective equipment are being employed. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 23 states, and the number of affected LGAs remains at 86.
