A total of 19 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 10 states: Edo (6), Ondo (4), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Delta (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states.\n- A total of 20 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment centre (9), Federal Medical Centre, Owo (9), and Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (1).\n- A total of 9321 contacts have been identified from 21 states. Of these, 347 (3.7%) are currently being followed up, 8894 (95.4%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 12 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. 144 symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 68 (47.2%) have tested positive.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate response activities at all levels.\n\nFigures [available at the source URL above]\n-------------------------------------------\nFigure 1 [map]. Randomised distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 2 [map]. LGAs with confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed cases (754) in Nigeria, week 1-47, 2019.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, week 1, 2016-week 47, 2019.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case-fatality rates (CFR) as at 24 Nov 2019.\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 24 Nov 2019.\n\n*Suspected case describes any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss, and either (a) history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents or (b) history of contact with a probably or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, or any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia.\n**Any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 8 new confirmed and 4681 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever (LF) virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria should be in the period of the year when fewer cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3 (at the source URL above), but more cases are still occurring. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (January-March) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again next year (2020).\n\nThe number of confirmed deaths has remained the same, 158. Fortunately, there are also no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 19, a likely indication that effective barrier nursing and the use of personal protective equipment are being employed. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 23 states, and the number of affected LGAs remains at 86. ProMED-mail readers may wish to see the maps and graphs (Figures 1-6) that are available at the source URL above.\n\nTransmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThere is no mention in the plans above of public education for avoidance of contact with these rodents and their excreta. - WEST AFRICA (27): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Nigeria CDC update\n[2] Emergency declared over\n\n******\n[1] Nigeria CDC update\nDate: Sun 19 May 2019\nSource: Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) situation report [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nHighlights\n- In the reporting week 20 (13-19 May 2019) 6 new confirmed cases were reported from 3 states: Edo (2), Ebonyi (2), and Ondo (2) states, with one new death from Edo state;\n- From 1 Jan-19 May 2019, a total of 2504 suspected cases have been reported from 21 states. Of these, 575 were confirmed positive, 15 were probable, and 1914 were negative (not a case) - Table 1 [tables and figures available at the source URL above];\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 129 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 22.4%;\n- 21 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi, and Cross River) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 82 local government areas [LGAs] - Figure 1;\n- 93% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (36%), Ondo (29%), Ebonyi (8%), Bauchi (7%), Taraba (7%), and Plateau (6%) states - Figure 1;\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-40 years (range: [greater than] one month to 89 years; median age: 32 years) - Figure 6;\n- The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1.2:1 - Figure 6;\n- In the reporting week 20, no new healthcare worker was affected. A total of 18 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 8 states: Edo (7), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states;\n- 5 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment Centre (1), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (2), Federal Medical Centre, Jalingo (1), and Kebbi (1);\n- A total of 7446 contacts have been identified from 20 states. Of these, 578 (7.8%) are currently being followed up, 6800 (91.3%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 8 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. A total of 119 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 60 (0.8%) have tested positive;\n- Multi-sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Kebbi state; and\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 2 [map]. LGA attack rate of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed (575) cases in Nigeria - week 01-20, 2019\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016-2019/week 20\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 6 new confirmed and 2504 suspected cases (up 2 from 4 confirmed and 2426 suspected cases in the report of week 19 [6-12 May 2019] indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria is still within the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (1 Jan-17 Mar 2019) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 129 confirmed deaths, with a 5-case increase from the previous reporting period. Fortunately, there are no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 18. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states and the number of affected LGAs remaining at 82.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] Emergency declared over\nDate: Fri 31 May 2019\nSource: NAIJ [edited]\nhttps://www.legit.ng/1241168-lassa-fever-after-129-deaths-fg-declares-emergency-phase-over.html\n\n\nFollowing a recent joint epidemiological review by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), WHO Nigeria, and other partners, the federal government on Friday [31 May 2019] declared that the emergency phase of Lassa fever is over.\n\nThis is coming after the bodies combated the disease that claimed not less than 129 lives across 21 states in the country. The statement that contained the declaration was co-signed by the NCDC's director general, Chikwe Ihekweazu, and Clement Peter, the officer-in-charge of the World Health Organization, Nigeria, (WHO), Premium Times reports.\n\nThe NCDC's boss said that due to an impressive response, the Lassa fever case count has notably dropped, such that the disease in the country has fallen below emergency levels. He said: \"This year [2019], there was also a decline in case fatality rate of Lassa fever, from 27% in 2018 to 22% in 2019.\" However, Ihekweazu said that the deadly disease is not yet over in the country, as there might be few cases of patients with the fever, adding that the agency will work with a multi-sectoral Lassa fever Technical Working Group for co-ordination of efforts. He said: \"Given that Lassa fever is endemic in Nigeria, it is likely that the country will continue to record cases of Lassa fever. \"The group's focus is to continue monitoring cases, as well as improve disease prevention, surveillance, diagnosis, and response activities across all levels in Nigeria.\n\n\"However, we have several research strategies to improve our knowledge of the disease. We are also working with states and partners to establish more long-term strategies, such as improved risk communication, infection prevention and control, regular environmental sanitation, enhanced capacity of health workers, and improvement of treatment centres, among others.\"\n\nOn his part, Peter said: \"WHO remains committed to working with the government of Nigeria and other partners to sustain and improve Nigeria's capacity to detect, prepare for, and respond to Lassa fever outbreaks, including implementing a Lassa fever research plan and other control strategies.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the emergency phase of this year's (2019's) outbreak has been declared over, new cases continue to occur. As the above comment indicated, there has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 over the past 3 years. Although Nigeria is reaching the end of the usual transmission period of January-June, cases can be expected to occur sporadically for the remainder of this year (2019). Avoidance of contact with reservoir rodents and their excrement will be essential to reduce cases of Lassa fever. Continuing public education will be required to accomplish this goal. That constitutes a daunting effort, considering the wide geographic area in which the virus is endemic. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - West Africa (26): Nigeria 20190521.6478581\nLassa fever - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6682237", "date": "2019-06-02 06:21:55", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (27): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Nigeria CDC update\n[2] Emergency declared over\n\n******\n[1] Nigeria CDC update\nDate: Sun 19 May 2019\nSource: Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) situation report [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nHighlights\n- In the reporting week 20 (13-19 May 2019) 6 new confirmed cases were reported from 3 states: Edo (2), Ebonyi (2), and Ondo (2) states, with one new death from Edo state;\n- From 1 Jan-19 May 2019, a total of 2504 suspected cases have been reported from 21 states. Of these, 575 were confirmed positive, 15 were probable, and 1914 were negative (not a case) - Table 1 [tables and figures available at the source URL above];\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 129 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 22.4%;\n- 21 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi, and Cross River) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 82 local government areas [LGAs] - Figure 1;\n- 93% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (36%), Ondo (29%), Ebonyi (8%), Bauchi (7%), Taraba (7%), and Plateau (6%) states - Figure 1;\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-40 years (range: [greater than] one month to 89 years; median age: 32 years) - Figure 6;\n- The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1.2:1 - Figure 6;\n- In the reporting week 20, no new healthcare worker was affected. A total of 18 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 8 states: Edo (7), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states;\n- 5 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment Centre (1), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (2), Federal Medical Centre, Jalingo (1), and Kebbi (1);\n- A total of 7446 contacts have been identified from 20 states. Of these, 578 (7.8%) are currently being followed up, 6800 (91.3%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 8 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. A total of 119 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 60 (0.8%) have tested positive;\n- Multi-sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Kebbi state; and\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 2 [map]. LGA attack rate of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed (575) cases in Nigeria - week 01-20, 2019\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016-2019/week 20\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 6 new confirmed and 2504 suspected cases (up 2 from 4 confirmed and 2426 suspected cases in the report of week 19 [6-12 May 2019] indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria is still within the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (1 Jan-17 Mar 2019) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 129 confirmed deaths, with a 5-case increase from the previous reporting period. Fortunately, there are no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 18. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states and the number of affected LGAs remaining at 82.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] Emergency declared over\nDate: Fri 31 May 2019\nSource: NAIJ [edited]\nhttps://www.legit.ng/1241168-lassa-fever-after-129-deaths-fg-declares-emergency-phase-over.html\n\n\nFollowing a recent joint epidemiological review by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), WHO Nigeria, and other partners, the federal government on Friday [31 May 2019] declared that the emergency phase of Lassa fever is over.\n\nThis is coming after the bodies combated the disease that claimed not less than 129 lives across 21 states in the country. The statement that contained the declaration was co-signed by the NCDC's director general, Chikwe Ihekweazu, and Clement Peter, the officer-in-charge of the World Health Organization, Nigeria, (WHO), Premium Times reports.\n\nThe NCDC's boss said that due to an impressive response, the Lassa fever case count has notably dropped, such that the disease in the country has fallen below emergency levels. He said: \"This year [2019], there was also a decline in case fatality rate of Lassa fever, from 27% in 2018 to 22% in 2019.\" However, Ihekweazu said that the deadly disease is not yet over in the country, as there might be few cases of patients with the fever, adding that the agency will work with a multi-sectoral Lassa fever Technical Working Group for co-ordination of efforts. He said: \"Given that Lassa fever is endemic in Nigeria, it is likely that the country will continue to record cases of Lassa fever. \"The group's focus is to continue monitoring cases, as well as improve disease prevention, surveillance, diagnosis, and response activities across all levels in Nigeria.\n\n\"However, we have several research strategies to improve our knowledge of the disease. We are also working with states and partners to establish more long-term strategies, such as improved risk communication, infection prevention and control, regular environmental sanitation, enhanced capacity of health workers, and improvement of treatment centres, among others.\"\n\nOn his part, Peter said: \"WHO remains committed to working with the government of Nigeria and other partners to sustain and improve Nigeria's capacity to detect, prepare for, and respond to Lassa fever outbreaks, including implementing a Lassa fever research plan and other control strategies.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the emergency phase of this year's (2019's) outbreak has been declared over, new cases continue to occur. As the above comment indicated, there has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 over the past 3 years. Although Nigeria is reaching the end of the usual transmission period of January-June, cases can be expected to occur sporadically for the remainder of this year (2019). Avoidance of contact with reservoir rodents and their excrement will be essential to reduce cases of Lassa fever. Continuing public education will be required to accomplish this goal. That constitutes a daunting effort, considering the wide geographic area in which the virus is endemic. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - West Africa (26): Nigeria 20190521.6478581\nLassa fever - [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=5&name=An%20update%20of%20Lassa%20fever%20outbreak%20in%20Nigeria\n\n\nHighlights\n- In the reporting week 20 (13-19 May 2019) 6 new confirmed cases were reported from 3 states: Edo (2), Ebonyi (2), and Ondo (2) states, with one new death from Edo state;\n- From 1 Jan-19 May 2019, a total of 2504 suspected cases have been reported from 21 states. Of these, 575 were confirmed positive, 15 were probable, and 1914 were negative (not a case) - Table 1 [tables and figures available at the source URL above];\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 129 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 22.4%;\n- 21 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi, and Cross River) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 82 local government areas [LGAs] - Figure 1;\n- 93% of all confirmed cases are from Edo (36%), Ondo (29%), Ebonyi (8%), Bauchi (7%), Taraba (7%), and Plateau (6%) states - Figure 1;\n- The predominant age group affected is 21-40 years (range: [greater than] one month to 89 years; median age: 32 years) - Figure 6;\n- The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1.2:1 - Figure 6;\n- In the reporting week 20, no new healthcare worker was affected. A total of 18 healthcare workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 8 states: Edo (7), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1), Benue (1), Plateau (1), and Kebbi (1), with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo states;\n- 5 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital (ISTH) treatment Centre (1), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (2), Federal Medical Centre, Jalingo (1), and Kebbi (1);\n- A total of 7446 contacts have been identified from 20 states. Of these, 578 (7.8%) are currently being followed up, 6800 (91.3%) have completed 21 days follow-up, while 8 (0.1%) were lost to follow-up. A total of 119 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 60 (0.8%) have tested positive;\n- Multi-sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Kebbi state; and\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 2 [map]. LGA attack rate of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed (575) cases in Nigeria - week 01-20, 2019\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016-2019/week 20\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state-specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 19 May 2019\nFigure 6 [graph]. Age-sex distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 19 May 2019\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 6 new confirmed and 2504 suspected cases (up 2 from 4 confirmed and 2426 suspected cases in the report of week 19 [6-12 May 2019] indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing. Nigeria is still within the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (1 Jan-17 Mar 2019) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 129 confirmed deaths, with a 5-case increase from the previous reporting period. Fortunately, there are no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 18. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states and the number of affected LGAs remaining at 82.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] Emergency declared over\nDate: Fri 31 May 2019\nSource: NAIJ [edited]\nhttps://www.legit.ng/1241168-lassa-fever-after-129-deaths-fg-declares-emergency-phase-over.html\n\n\nFollowing a recent joint epidemiological review by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), WHO Nigeria, and other partners, the federal government on Friday [31 May 2019] declared that the emergency phase of Lassa fever is over.\n\nThis is coming after the bodies combated the disease that claimed not less than 129 lives across 21 states in the country. The statement that contained the declaration was co-signed by the NCDC's director general, Chikwe Ihekweazu, and Clement Peter, the officer-in-charge of the World Health Organization, Nigeria, (WHO), Premium Times reports.\n\nThe NCDC's boss said that due to an impressive response, the Lassa fever case count has notably dropped, such that the disease in the country has fallen below emergency levels. He said: \"This year [2019], there was also a decline in case fatality rate of Lassa fever, from 27% in 2018 to 22% in 2019.\" However, Ihekweazu said that the deadly disease is not yet over in the country, as there might be few cases of patients with the fever, adding that the agency will work with a multi-sectoral Lassa fever Technical Working Group for co-ordination of efforts. He said: \"Given that Lassa fever is endemic in Nigeria, it is likely that the country will continue to record cases of Lassa fever. \"The group's focus is to continue monitoring cases, as well as improve disease prevention, surveillance, diagnosis, and response activities across all levels in Nigeria.\n\n\"However, we have several research strategies to improve our knowledge of the disease. We are also working with states and partners to establish more long-term strategies, such as improved risk communication, infection prevention and control, regular environmental sanitation, enhanced capacity of health workers, and improvement of treatment centres, among others.\"\n\nOn his part, Peter said: \"WHO remains committed to working with the government of Nigeria and other partners to sustain and improve Nigeria's capacity to detect, prepare for, and respond to Lassa fever outbreaks, including implementing a Lassa fever research plan and other control strategies.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the emergency phase of this year's (2019's) outbreak has been declared over, new cases continue to occur. As the above comment indicated, there has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 over the past 3 years. Although Nigeria is reaching the end of the usual transmission period of January-June, cases can be expected to occur sporadically for the remainder of this year (2019). Avoidance of contact with reservoir rodents and their excrement will be essential to reduce cases of Lassa fever. Continuing public education will be required to accomplish this goal. That constitutes a daunting effort, considering the wide geographic area in which the virus is endemic. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - West Africa (26): Nigeria 20190521.6478581\nLassa fever - A total of 119 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 60 (0.8%) have tested positive;\n- Multi-sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Kebbi state; and\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Technical Working Group (TWG) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Nigeria is still within the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 (1 Jan-17 Mar 2019) over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 129 confirmed deaths, with a 5-case increase from the previous reporting period. Fortunately, there are no new healthcare workers infected during this reporting period, and the total number of infected healthcare workers remains at 18. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states and the number of affected LGAs remaining at 82.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] Emergency declared over\nDate: Fri 31 May 2019\nSource: NAIJ [edited]\nhttps://www.legit.ng/1241168-lassa-fever-after-129-deaths-fg-declares-emergency-phase-over.html\n\n\nFollowing a recent joint epidemiological review by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), WHO Nigeria, and other partners, the federal government on Friday [31 May 2019] declared that the emergency phase of Lassa fever is over.\n\nThis is coming after the bodies combated the disease that claimed not less than 129 lives across 21 states in the country. The statement that contained the declaration was co-signed by the NCDC's director general, Chikwe Ihekweazu, and Clement Peter, the officer-in-charge of the World Health Organization, Nigeria, (WHO), Premium Times reports.\n\nThe NCDC's boss said that due to an impressive response, the Lassa fever case count has notably dropped, such that the disease in the country has fallen below emergency levels. He said: \"This year [2019], there was also a decline in case fatality rate of Lassa fever, from 27% in 2018 to 22% in 2019.\" However, Ihekweazu said that the deadly disease is not yet over in the country, as there might be few cases of patients with the fever, adding that the agency will work with a multi-sectoral Lassa fever Technical Working Group for co-ordination of efforts. He said: \"Given that Lassa fever is endemic in Nigeria, it is likely that the country will continue to record cases of Lassa fever. \"The group's focus is to continue monitoring cases, as well as improve disease prevention, surveillance, diagnosis, and response activities across all levels in Nigeria.\n\n\"However, we have several research strategies to improve our knowledge of the disease. We are also working with states and partners to establish more long-term strategies, such as improved risk communication, infection prevention and control, regular environmental sanitation, enhanced capacity of health workers, and improvement of treatment centres, among others.\"\n\nOn his part, Peter said: \"WHO remains committed to working with the government of Nigeria and other partners to sustain and improve Nigeria's capacity to detect, prepare for, and respond to Lassa fever outbreaks, including implementing a Lassa fever research plan and other control strategies.\"\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the emergency phase of this year's (2019's) outbreak has been declared over, new cases continue to occur. As the above comment indicated, there has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 and 11 over the past 3 years. Although Nigeria is reaching the end of the usual transmission period of January-June, cases can be expected to occur sporadically for the remainder of this year (2019). Avoidance of contact with reservoir rodents and their excrement will be essential to reduce cases of Lassa fever. Continuing public education will be required to accomplish this goal. That constitutes a daunting effort, considering the wide geographic area in which the virus is endemic. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - West Africa (26): Nigeria 20190521.6478581\nLassa fever - West Africa (25): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6453789", "date": "2019-03-24 12:36:54", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (19): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2019\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/d3cfc533ee17f071904aa4aec5f764cc.pdf\n\n\nHighlights\n- In the reporting Week 11 (11 - 17 Mar 2019) 23 new confirmed cases were reported from 9 states - Edo (8), Ondo 4), Ebonyi (3), Bauchi (3), Taraba (1), Imo (1), Enugu (1), Benue (1) and Kebbi (1) with 4 new deaths in Edo (2), Benue (1) and Bauchi (1) States\n- From 1 Jan - 17 Mar 2019, a total of 1801 suspected cases have been reported from states. Of these, 495 were confirmed positive, 15 probable and 1277 negative (not a case)-Table 1\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 114 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 23.0%\n- 21 States (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi and Cross River) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 73 Local Government Areas- Figure 1\n- In the reporting week 11, one new health care worker was affected in Ebonyi state. A total of 16 health care workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 7 States - Edo (7), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo States\n- 63 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital(ISTH) treatment Centre (26), Federal Medical Centre Owo (16), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (10), Nasarawa(1), Bauchi(1), Plateau (3), Taraba (4) and others (2)\n- A total of 5790 contacts have been identified from 19 States. Of these 2353 (40.6%) are currently being followed up, 3384 (58.4%) have completed 21 days follow up, while 4 (0.1%) were lost to follow up. 84 (1.5%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 49(1.0%) have tested positive\n- Assessment of the 2 treatment centres in Plateau state by NCDC case management team\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre(EOC) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Distribution of Confirmed Lassa Fever cases in Nigeria as at 17 Mar 2019\nFigure 2 [map]. LGA attack rate of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 17 Mar 2019\nFigure 3 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state specific Case Fatality Rates (CFR) as at 17 Mar 2019\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 52 new confirmed and 1801 suspected cases (up from 52 confirmed and 1374 suspected cases in the previous report) indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing, as Nigeria is now well within the period of the year when more cases usually occur, as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 - 11 over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 114 confirmed deaths, up from 93 in the previous reporting period. Unfortunately, one new healthcare worker was infected during this reporting period, and the total infected healthcare workers is 16. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states, and the number of affected LGAs has increased from 66 2 previous reporting periods ago to 73 at week 11.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/.\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - 17 Mar 2019) 23 new confirmed cases were reported from 9 states - Edo (8), Ondo 4), Ebonyi (3), Bauchi (3), Taraba (1), Imo (1), Enugu (1), Benue (1) and Kebbi (1) with 4 new deaths in Edo (2), Benue (1) and Bauchi (1) States\n- From 1 Jan - 17 Mar 2019, a total of 1801 suspected cases have been reported from states. Of these, 495 were confirmed positive, 15 probable and 1277 negative (not a case)-Table 1\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 114 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 23.0%\n- 21 States (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo, Kebbi and Cross River) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 73 Local Government Areas- Figure 1\n- In the reporting week 11, one new health care worker was affected in Ebonyi state. A total of 16 health care workers have been infected since the onset of the outbreak in 7 States - Edo (7), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (2), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) with 2 deaths in Enugu and Edo States\n- 63 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital(ISTH) treatment Centre (26), Federal Medical Centre Owo (16), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakaliki (10), Nasarawa(1), Bauchi(1), Plateau (3), Taraba (4) and others (2)\n- A total of 5790 contacts have been identified from 19 States. Of these 2353 (40.6%) are currently being followed up, 3384 (58.4%) have completed 21 days follow up, while 4 (0.1%) were lost to follow up. 84 (1.5%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 49(1.0%) have tested positive\n- Assessment of the 2 treatment centres in Plateau state by NCDC case management team\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre(EOC) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels\n\nFigure 1 [map]. Distribution of Confirmed Lassa Fever cases in Nigeria as at 17 Mar 2019\nFigure 2 [map]. LGA attack rate of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as at 17 Mar 2019\nFigure 3 [graph]. There has been a peak in case numbers between weeks 1 - 11 over the past 3 years and probably will be the case again this year (2019). There are 114 confirmed deaths, up from 93 in the previous reporting period. Unfortunately, one new healthcare worker was infected during this reporting period, and the total infected healthcare workers is 16. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states, and the number of affected LGAs has increased from 66 2 previous reporting periods ago to 73 at week 11.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/.\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Unfortunately, one new healthcare worker was infected during this reporting period, and the total infected healthcare workers is 16. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, with confirmed cases occurring in 21 states, and the number of affected LGAs has increased from 66 2 previous reporting periods ago to 73 at week 11.\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. 10 Feb 2019, a total of 947 suspected cases have been reported from 20 states and FCT. Of these, 324 were confirmed positive, 3 probable and 620 negative (not a case) - Figure 1.\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 69 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 21.3%.\n- 20 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo and Kebbi) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 54 local government areas [LGA] - Figure 1.\n- In the reporting week 6, 3 new healthcare workers were affected in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers State. A total of 12 health care workers have been affected since the onset of the outbreak in 7 States; Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) with one death in Enugu.\n- 91 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital(ISTH) treatment Centre (32), Federal Medical Centre Owo (31), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakiliki (6), Bauchi (3), Plateau (7) and others (12) states.\n- A total of 3746 contacts have been identified from 18 states. Of these 2658 (72.0%) are currently being followed up, 1045 (27.9%) have completed 21 days follow up, while 4 (0.1%) were lost to follow up. 60 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 39 (1.0%) have tested positive.\n- Multi sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, Federal Ministry of Agricultural and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau and Bauchi.\n- Mid outbreak review meeting scheduled for 15 Feb 2019.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map].Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as of 10 Feb 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed 324 cases in Nigeria week 2018/week 51-2019/week 6.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016/week 01-2019/week 6.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 10 Feb 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 37 new confirmed and 731 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing as Nigeria is now in the period of the year when more cases usually occur as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There are 69 confirmed deaths, up from 51 in the previous reporting period. Unfortunately, 3 new healthcare workers, one each in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers States, were infected during this reporting period. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, occurring in 20 states (up from 19 in a previous reporting period) and 54 LGAs (up from 51 in the previous reporting period).\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria:\nhttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] WHO\nDate: Thu 14 Feb 2019\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/14-february-2019-lassa-fever-nigeria/en/\n\n\nFrom 1 Jan - 10 Feb 2019, 327 cases of Lassa fever (324 confirmed cases and 3 probable cases) with 72 deaths (case fatality ratio 22%) have been reported across 20 states and the Federal Capital Territory, with the majority of cases being reported from Edo (108) and Ondo (103) states. A total of 12 cases have been reported among healthcare workers in 7 states - Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) including one death in Enugu.\n\nThe number of confirmed cases reported across Nigeria remains high. In week 6, 2019 (week ending 10 Feb 2019), 37 new confirmed cases including 10 deaths (case fatality ratio 27%) were reported from 9 states across Nigeria. The majority of cases were reported from Ondo (12) and Edo (10) states. The number of confirmed cases reported in week 6, 2019, represents a slight decrease compared to week 5 when 68 confirmed cases were reported (Figure 1).\n\nOf the 3746 contacts identified since January 2019, 2658 are still under follow-up while 1045 have completed 21 days of follow-up. As many as 60 contacts became symptomatic, of which 39 tested positive.\n\nA total 91 case-patients are currently in admission at treatment centers across the country. The case-patients are being treated with standard supportive care.\n\nFigure 1: Number of confirmed and probable Lassa fever cases in Nigeria reported by the week of illness onset from 1 Jan through 10 Feb 2019\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- On 22 Jan 2019, the Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) declared the outbreak an emergency.\n- Multi-sectoral One Health national rapid response teams have been deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau, and Bauchi to support field investigation and response activities.\n- Enhanced surveillance is ongoing in all states following alert communication and a press release from NCDC.\n- Treatment of Lassa fever cases is also ongoing at designated treatment centres across the country.\n- Risk communication and community engagement activities continue in the states. National awareness was improved through the recently concluded international Lassa fever conference which took place from 16 -17 Jan 2019.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nLassa fever is a viral haemorrhagic fever that is transmitted to humans via contact with food or household items contaminated with rodent urine or faeces. Person-to-person infections and laboratory transmission can also occur. The overall case fatality rate is 1%; it is 15% among patients hospitalized with severe illness. There is currently no approved vaccine. Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival.\n\nAlthough Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June, the current increase in new confirmed cases and deaths should be monitored closely and addressed appropriately. Cases in neigbouring Benin and Togo potentially originating from Nigeria have been reported in previous years and therefore neighbouring countries should be monitored accordingly.\n\nWith 12 confirmed cases so far among healthcare workers, there is evidence of nosocomial transmission of the disease amidst reports of inadequate infection prevention and control (IPC) supplied in some health facilities and complacency on the part of health workers towards maintaining IPC measures.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nPrevention of Lassa fever relies on community engagement and promoting hygienic conditions to discourage rodents from entering homes. In healthcare settings, staff should consistently implement standard infection prevention and control measures when caring for patients to prevent nosocomial infections. WHO continues to advice all countries in the Lassa fever belt on the need to enhance early detection and treatment of cases to reduce the case fatality rate as well as strengthen cross-border collaboration.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the currently available information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The WHO recommended community engagement is a challenge, given the broad geographical area in which cases are occurring. A proactive public education effort is required to encourage use of containers that prevent rodent access to food materials and blocking of entry points of the rodents into houses.\n\nInterestingly, although the WHO does not recommend travel restrictions, on 7 Feb 2019 the USA CDC has recommended taking precautions in its updated travel advisory for Nigeria due to the recent Lassa fever cases, stating, \"Travelers to Nigeria should avoid contact with rats, especially rat urine and feces, and take precautions to keep their accommodations clean and free of rodents. If you need to clean up after rodents, take the proper steps to avoid getting sick. Travelers should also wash hands often, and avoid contact with people who are sick. Travelers who develop fever or other serious symptoms of Lassa fever during or after their trip should see a doctor right away. They should tell the doctor where they traveled in Nigeria and whether they had contact with a rodent or sick person.\" (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/lassa-fever-nigeria). - Mod.TY\n]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - In week 6, 2019 (week ending 10 Feb 2019), 37 new confirmed cases including 10 deaths (case fatality ratio 27%) were reported from 9 states across Nigeria. The majority of cases were reported from Ondo (12) and Edo (10) states. The number of confirmed cases reported in week 6, 2019, represents a slight decrease compared to week 5 when 68 confirmed cases were reported (Figure 1).\n\nOf the 3746 contacts identified since January 2019, 2658 are still under follow-up while 1045 have completed 21 days of follow-up. As many as 60 contacts became symptomatic, of which 39 tested positive.\n\nA total 91 case-patients are currently in admission at treatment centers across the country. The case-patients are being treated with standard supportive care.\n\nFigure 1: Number of confirmed and probable Lassa fever cases in Nigeria reported by the week of illness onset from 1 Jan through 10 Feb 2019\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- On 22 Jan 2019, the Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) declared the outbreak an emergency.\n- Multi-sectoral One Health national rapid response teams have been deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau, and Bauchi to support field investigation and response activities.\n- Enhanced surveillance is ongoing in all states following alert communication and a press release from NCDC.\n- Treatment of Lassa fever cases is also ongoing at designated treatment centres across the country.\n- Risk communication and community engagement activities continue in the states. National awareness was improved through the recently concluded international Lassa fever conference which took place from 16 -17 Jan 2019.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nLassa fever is a viral haemorrhagic fever that is transmitted to humans via contact with food or household items contaminated with rodent urine or faeces. Person-to-person infections and laboratory transmission can also occur. The overall case fatality rate is 1%; it is 15% among patients hospitalized with severe illness. There is currently no approved vaccine. Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival.\n\nAlthough Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June, the current increase in new confirmed cases and deaths should be monitored closely and addressed appropriately. Cases in neigbouring Benin and Togo potentially originating from Nigeria have been reported in previous years and therefore neighbouring countries should be monitored accordingly.\n\nWith 12 confirmed cases so far among healthcare workers, there is evidence of nosocomial transmission of the disease amidst reports of inadequate infection prevention and control (IPC) supplied in some health facilities and complacency on the part of health workers towards maintaining IPC measures.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nPrevention of Lassa fever relies on community engagement and promoting hygienic conditions to discourage rodents from entering homes. In healthcare settings, staff should consistently implement standard infection prevention and control measures when caring for patients to prevent nosocomial infections. WHO continues to advice all countries in the Lassa fever belt on the need to enhance early detection and treatment of cases to reduce the case fatality rate as well as strengthen cross-border collaboration.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the currently available information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The WHO recommended community engagement is a challenge, given the broad geographical area in which cases are occurring. A proactive public education effort is required to encourage use of containers that prevent rodent access to food materials and blocking of entry points of the rodents into houses.\n\nInterestingly, although the WHO does not recommend travel restrictions, on 7 Feb 2019 the USA CDC has recommended taking precautions in its updated travel advisory for Nigeria due to the recent Lassa fever cases, stating, \"Travelers to Nigeria should avoid contact with rats, especially rat urine and feces, and take precautions to keep their accommodations clean and free of rodents. If you need to clean up after rodents, take the proper steps to avoid getting sick. Travelers should also wash hands often, and avoid contact with people who are sick. Travelers who develop fever or other serious symptoms of Lassa fever during or after their trip should see a doctor right away. They should tell the doctor where they traveled in Nigeria and whether they had contact with a rodent or sick person.\" (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/lassa-fever-nigeria). - Mod.TY\n]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - They should tell the doctor where they traveled in Nigeria and whether they had contact with a rodent or sick person.\" (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/lassa-fever-nigeria). - Mod.TY\n]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - West Africa (14): Nigeria (PL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6331712", "date": "2019-02-18 14:27:09", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (11): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Nigeria CDC\n[2] WHO\n\n******\n[1] Nigeria CDC\nDate: Sat 10 Feb 2019\nSource: Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]\nhttps://ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/b94e459c79a59ca9d667a55539cda5db.pdf\n\n\nHighlights\n----------\n- In the reporting week 6 (4-10 Feb 2019) 37 new confirmed cases were reported from Edo (10), Ondo (12), Ebonyi (4), Plateau (4), Taraba (3), Benue (1), Gombe (1), Rivers (1) and Kebbi (1) states with 10 new deaths in Edo (2), Ondo (2), Ebonyi (4) and Plateau (2).\n- From 1 Jan - 10 Feb 2019, a total of 947 suspected cases have been reported from 20 states and FCT. Of these, 324 were confirmed positive, 3 probable and 620 negative (not a case) - Figure 1.\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 69 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 21.3%.\n- 20 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo and Kebbi) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 54 local government areas [LGA] - Figure 1.\n- In the reporting week 6, 3 new healthcare workers were affected in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers State. A total of 12 health care workers have been affected since the onset of the outbreak in 7 States; Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) with one death in Enugu.\n- 91 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital(ISTH) treatment Centre (32), Federal Medical Centre Owo (31), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakiliki (6), Bauchi (3), Plateau (7) and others (12) states.\n- A total of 3746 contacts have been identified from 18 states. Of these 2658 (72.0%) are currently being followed up, 1045 (27.9%) have completed 21 days follow up, while 4 (0.1%) were lost to follow up. 60 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 39 (1.0%) have tested positive.\n- Multi sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, Federal Ministry of Agricultural and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau and Bauchi.\n- Mid outbreak review meeting scheduled for 15 Feb 2019.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map].Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as of 10 Feb 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed 324 cases in Nigeria week 2018/week 51-2019/week 6.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016/week 01-2019/week 6.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 10 Feb 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 37 new confirmed and 731 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing as Nigeria is now in the period of the year when more cases usually occur as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There are 69 confirmed deaths, up from 51 in the previous reporting period. Unfortunately, 3 new healthcare workers, one each in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers States, were infected during this reporting period. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, occurring in 20 states (up from 19 in a previous reporting period) and 54 LGAs (up from 51 in the previous reporting period).\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria:\nhttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] WHO\nDate: Thu 14 Feb 2019\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/14-february-2019-lassa-fever-nigeria/en/\n\n\nFrom 1 Jan - 10 Feb 2019, 327 cases of Lassa fever (324 confirmed cases and 3 probable cases) with 72 deaths (case fatality ratio 22%) have been reported across 20 states and the Federal Capital Territory, with the majority of cases being reported from Edo (108) and Ondo (103) states. A total of 12 cases have been reported among healthcare workers in 7 states - Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) including one death in Enugu.\n\nThe number of confirmed cases reported across Nigeria remains high. In week 6, 2019 (week ending 10 Feb 2019), 37 new confirmed cases including 10 deaths (case fatality ratio 27%) were reported from 9 states across Nigeria. The majority of cases were reported from Ondo (12) and Edo (10) states. The number of confirmed cases reported in week 6, 2019, represents a slight decrease compared to week 5 when 68 confirmed cases were reported (Figure 1).\n\nOf the 3746 contacts identified since January 2019, 2658 are still under follow-up while 1045 have completed 21 days of follow-up. As many as 60 contacts became symptomatic, of which 39 tested positive.\n\nA total 91 case-patients are currently in admission at treatment centers across the country. The case-patients are being treated with standard supportive care.\n\nFigure 1: Number of confirmed and probable Lassa fever cases in Nigeria reported by the week of illness onset from 1 Jan through 10 Feb 2019\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- On 22 Jan 2019, the Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) declared the outbreak an emergency.\n- Multi-sectoral One Health national rapid response teams have been deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau, and Bauchi to support field investigation and response activities.\n- Enhanced surveillance is ongoing in all states following alert communication and a press release from NCDC.\n- Treatment of Lassa fever cases is also ongoing at designated treatment centres across the country.\n- Risk communication and community engagement activities continue in the states. National awareness was improved through the recently concluded international Lassa fever conference which took place from 16 -17 Jan 2019.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nLassa fever is a viral haemorrhagic fever that is transmitted to humans via contact with food or household items contaminated with rodent urine or faeces. Person-to-person infections and laboratory transmission can also occur. The overall case fatality rate is 1%; it is 15% among patients hospitalized with severe illness. There is currently no approved vaccine. Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival.\n\nAlthough Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June, the current increase in new confirmed cases and deaths should be monitored closely and addressed appropriately. Cases in neigbouring Benin and Togo potentially originating from Nigeria have been reported in previous years and therefore neighbouring countries should be monitored accordingly.\n\nWith 12 confirmed cases so far among healthcare workers, there is evidence of nosocomial transmission of the disease amidst reports of inadequate infection prevention and control (IPC) supplied in some health facilities and complacency on the part of health workers towards maintaining IPC measures.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nPrevention of Lassa fever relies on community engagement and promoting hygienic conditions to discourage rodents from entering homes. In healthcare settings, staff should consistently implement standard infection prevention and control measures when caring for patients to prevent nosocomial infections. WHO continues to advice all countries in the Lassa fever belt on the need to enhance early detection and treatment of cases to reduce the case fatality rate as well as strengthen cross-border collaboration.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the currently available information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The WHO recommended community engagement is a challenge, given the broad geographical area in which cases are occurring. A proactive public education effort is required to encourage use of containers that prevent rodent access to food materials and blocking of entry points of the rodents into houses.\n\nInterestingly, although the WHO does not recommend travel restrictions, on 7 Feb 2019 the USA CDC has recommended taking precautions in its updated travel advisory for Nigeria due to the recent Lassa fever cases, stating, \"Travelers to Nigeria should avoid contact with rats, especially rat urine and feces, and take precautions to keep their accommodations clean and free of rodents. If you need to clean up after rodents, take the proper steps to avoid getting sick. Travelers should also wash hands often, and avoid contact with people who are sick. Travelers who develop fever or other serious symptoms of Lassa fever during or after their trip should see a doctor right away. They should tell the doctor where they traveled in Nigeria and whether they had contact with a rodent or sick person.\" (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/lassa-fever-nigeria). - Mod.TY\n]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Of these, 324 were confirmed positive, 3 probable and 620 negative (not a case) - Figure 1.\n- Since the onset of the 2019 outbreak, there have been 69 deaths in confirmed cases. Case fatality ratio in confirmed cases is 21.3%.\n- 20 states (Edo, Ondo, Bauchi, Nasarawa, Ebonyi, Plateau, Taraba, FCT, Adamawa, Gombe, Kaduna, Kwara, Benue, Rivers, Kogi, Enugu, Imo, Delta, Oyo and Kebbi) have recorded at least one confirmed case across 54 local government areas [LGA] - Figure 1.\n- In the reporting week 6, 3 new healthcare workers were affected in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers State. A total of 12 health care workers have been affected since the onset of the outbreak in 7 States; Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) with one death in Enugu.\n- 91 patients are currently being managed at various treatment centres across the country: Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital(ISTH) treatment Centre (32), Federal Medical Centre Owo (31), Federal Teaching Hospital Abakiliki (6), Bauchi (3), Plateau (7) and others (12) states.\n- A total of 3746 contacts have been identified from 18 states. Of these 2658 (72.0%) are currently being followed up, 1045 (27.9%) have completed 21 days follow up, while 4 (0.1%) were lost to follow up. 60 (1.6%) symptomatic contacts have been identified, of which 39 (1.0%) have tested positive.\n- Multi sectoral one health national rapid response teams (NCDC, NFELTP, Federal Ministry of Agricultural and Federal Ministry of Environment) deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau and Bauchi.\n- Mid outbreak review meeting scheduled for 15 Feb 2019.\n- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) continues to coordinate the response activities at all levels.\n\nFigure 1 [map].Distribution of confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria as of 10 Feb 2019.\nFigure 3 [graph]. Epicurve of Lassa fever confirmed 324 cases in Nigeria week 2018/week 51-2019/week 6.\nFigure 4 [graph]. Weekly trends of Lassa fever confirmed cases in Nigeria, 2016/week 01-2019/week 6.\nFigure 5 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria with state specific case fatality rates (CFR) as at 10 Feb 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 37 new confirmed and 731 suspected cases indicate that Lassa fever virus transmission is continuing as Nigeria is now in the period of the year when more cases usually occur as illustrated in the graph in Figure 3. There are 69 confirmed deaths, up from 51 in the previous reporting period. Unfortunately, 3 new healthcare workers, one each in Benue, Bauchi and Rivers States, were infected during this reporting period. This outbreak remains widespread so far in 2019, occurring in 20 states (up from 19 in a previous reporting period) and 54 LGAs (up from 51 in the previous reporting period).\n\nTransmission of Lassa virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir hosts' excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It would be interesting to know whether the prevalence of Lassa fever virus has been increasing in populations of rodent hosts in areas where human cases are occurring.\n\nImages of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:\n_Mastomys natalensis_: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis\n_Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: http://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/\n\nThe maps and graphs in the report above are interesting and provide a good picture of how the outbreak has progressed over time. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Nigeria:\nhttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62]\n\n******\n[2] WHO\nDate: Thu 14 Feb 2019\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/14-february-2019-lassa-fever-nigeria/en/\n\n\nFrom 1 Jan - 10 Feb 2019, 327 cases of Lassa fever (324 confirmed cases and 3 probable cases) with 72 deaths (case fatality ratio 22%) have been reported across 20 states and the Federal Capital Territory, with the majority of cases being reported from Edo (108) and Ondo (103) states. A total of 12 cases have been reported among healthcare workers in 7 states - Edo (4), Ondo (3), Ebonyi (1), Enugu (1), Rivers (1), Bauchi (1) and Benue (1) including one death in Enugu.\n\nThe number of confirmed cases reported across Nigeria remains high. In week 6, 2019 (week ending 10 Feb 2019), 37 new confirmed cases including 10 deaths (case fatality ratio 27%) were reported from 9 states across Nigeria. The majority of cases were reported from Ondo (12) and Edo (10) states. The number of confirmed cases reported in week 6, 2019, represents a slight decrease compared to week 5 when 68 confirmed cases were reported (Figure 1).\n\nOf the 3746 contacts identified since January 2019, 2658 are still under follow-up while 1045 have completed 21 days of follow-up. As many as 60 contacts became symptomatic, of which 39 tested positive.\n\nA total 91 case-patients are currently in admission at treatment centers across the country. The case-patients are being treated with standard supportive care.\n\nFigure 1: Number of confirmed and probable Lassa fever cases in Nigeria reported by the week of illness onset from 1 Jan through 10 Feb 2019\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- On 22 Jan 2019, the Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) declared the outbreak an emergency.\n- Multi-sectoral One Health national rapid response teams have been deployed to Ondo, Edo, Ebonyi, Plateau, and Bauchi to support field investigation and response activities.\n- Enhanced surveillance is ongoing in all states following alert communication and a press release from NCDC.\n- Treatment of Lassa fever cases is also ongoing at designated treatment centres across the country.\n- Risk communication and community engagement activities continue in the states. National awareness was improved through the recently concluded international Lassa fever conference which took place from 16 -17 Jan 2019.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nLassa fever is a viral haemorrhagic fever that is transmitted to humans via contact with food or household items contaminated with rodent urine or faeces. Person-to-person infections and laboratory transmission can also occur. The overall case fatality rate is 1%; it is 15% among patients hospitalized with severe illness. There is currently no approved vaccine. Early supportive care with rehydration and symptomatic treatment improves survival.\n\nAlthough Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June, the current increase in new confirmed cases and deaths should be monitored closely and addressed appropriately. Cases in neigbouring Benin and Togo potentially originating from Nigeria have been reported in previous years and therefore neighbouring countries should be monitored accordingly.\n\nWith 12 confirmed cases so far among healthcare workers, there is evidence of nosocomial transmission of the disease amidst reports of inadequate infection prevention and control (IPC) supplied in some health facilities and complacency on the part of health workers towards maintaining IPC measures.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nPrevention of Lassa fever relies on community engagement and promoting hygienic conditions to discourage rodents from entering homes. In healthcare settings, staff should consistently implement standard infection prevention and control measures when caring for patients to prevent nosocomial infections. WHO continues to advice all countries in the Lassa fever belt on the need to enhance early detection and treatment of cases to reduce the case fatality rate as well as strengthen cross-border collaboration.\n\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction to Nigeria based on the currently available information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The WHO recommended community engagement is a challenge, given the broad geographical area in which cases are occurring. A proactive public education effort is required to encourage use of containers that prevent rodent access to food materials and blocking of entry points of the rodents into houses.\n\nInterestingly, although the WHO does not recommend travel restrictions, on 7 Feb 2019 the USA CDC has recommended taking precautions in its updated travel advisory for Nigeria due to the recent Lassa fever cases, stating, \"Travelers to Nigeria should avoid contact with rats, especially rat urine and feces, and take precautions to keep their accommodations clean and free of rodents. If you need to clean up after rodents, take the proper steps to avoid getting sick. Travelers should also wash hands often, and avoid contact with people who are sick. Travelers who develop fever or other serious symptoms of Lassa fever during or after their trip should see a doctor right away. They should tell the doctor where they traveled in Nigeria and whether they had contact with a rodent or sick person.\" (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/lassa-fever-nigeria). - Mod.TY\n]\nSee Also\nLassa fever -
