West Africa (24): Nigeria (KT, KD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4143654", "date": "2016-03-19 13:37:57", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (18): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Mar 2016\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/17/health/lassa-fever-outbreak-nigeria/index.html\n\n\nMore than 130 people are suspected to have died from a Lassa fever outbreak in Nigeria, according to statistics from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).\n\nThe disease can cause fever and haemorrhaging of various parts of the body -- including the eyes and nose -- and can spread through contact with an infected rat. Person to person transmission is also possible, albeit less common.\n\nFor people witnessing the symptoms, alarm bells may ring and raise fears of Ebola -- but this is not Ebola.\n\nWest Africa as a region is seeing a flare-up of the disease, but Nigeria -- where Lassa fever was first discovered in 1969 -- is experiencing much higher mortality rates than usual.\n\nOn average, Lassa fever is deadly in 1 percent of all individuals infected, with higher rates of 15 percent morbidity among people hospitalized for the illness, but the current outbreak in Nigeria has seen more than 50 percent of those affected dying from their infection.\n\nAccording to NCDC's latest report, dated 14 Mar 2016, the total number of reported cases is 254 (129 of which confirmed by lab tests) and the total number of deaths (suspected, probable and confirmed) is 137, with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 53.9 percent.\n\nA 2012 outbreak of Lassa fever in Nigeria caused more than 1700 people to become infected, but 112 deaths, according to the Nigerian Center for Disease Control (NCDC). Despite lower case numbers, the death toll in the current outbreak are already higher.\n\n\"The deaths among cases are higher than normal, and we are currently establishing the reason for this,\" says Abdulsalami Nasidi, Director of the NCDC.\n\nA further concern is the geographic spread of the outbreak: \"More states are affected (than usual), and we're evaluating possible reasons,\" says Nasidi.\n\nLassa fever outbreaks occur most years in West Africa, as the disease is endemic to Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and Nigeria.\n\nEach year, the virus infects an estimated 100 000-300 000 and is responsible for 5000 deaths in the region as a whole.\n\nLassa virus is in the same family of viruses as Ebola and Marburg virus, which also cause fever and sometimes haemorrhage. [This is not correct. Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus and Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses. - Mod.TY]. The virus is named after the Nigerian town of Lassa where it was first discovered.\n\nOutbreaks generally occur during the region's dry season -- typically between November to February -- but this time it's persisting. Officials are speculating on the reasons for the increased mortality and spread, but the truth remains unknown. \"Viruses change over time,\" says Nasidi.\n\nOne theory officials are suggesting for the spread of the virus into new states, is that there may be better awareness of symptoms after the 2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa, which has infected more than 28 000 people. Previously, infections often went unreported as the disease mainly affects rural areas where populations can be highly infected, but don't notify the authorities.\n\nThe main culprit behind the transmission of Lassa fever is the \"multimammate rat\" -- a reservoir for the virus with the ability to spread it to humans. Touching, consuming, or inhaling, the urine or feces of a rat carrying the virus is the prime route of infection in humans. This generally happens through contaminated food and surfaces within people's homes -- particularly during the dry season.\n\n\"When the rains are over, the rats then come closer to humans to steal grains,\" says David Heymann, Professor of Infectious Disease Epidemiology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. In rural areas, communities often store grains in their homes after the harvest to get them through the dry season. \"They [the rodents] urinate and defecate on the rice, which makes the uncooked rice a source of human infection,\" says Heymann. The meat of rodents is often eaten in the region, further increasing the likelihood of transmission.\n\nContact with the bodily fluids, or tissues, of another human carrying the virus is also a mode of transmission, but more rare.\n\nThe symptoms of the disease are wide-ranging and vary from mild to severe in different cases, making diagnosis a challenge.\n\nOne in 5 of those infected will experience symptoms including haemorrhage, respiratory problems, and facial swelling, especially if diagnosed late with the disease, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The remaining 80 percent experience much milder symptoms such as fever and weakness, which can often go undiagnosed. Up to 1/3 of people infected also risk losing their hearing.\n\nTreatment is available with the antiviral drug ribavirin, but this has its greatest effect if used early.\n\nThe NCDC and Ministry of Health have increased resources to handle the outbreak, such as mapping those at most risk, improving access to diagnostics and engaging with communities to recognize the signs and symptoms. \"Every life counts and every case must be investigated,\" says Nasidi.\n\nGiven the increased mortality, the priority is prevention. This includes reducing the chances of contact between humans and rat colonies.\n\nSales of rat poison in Nigeria have boomed since the outbreak was announced, according to reports by the news service AFP.\n\nAs with Ebola, awareness and increased use of personal protective equipment when handling patients is also crucial to prevent human to human transmission, particularly in health clinics. \"The government has made the right recommendations about infection control in health facilities...the virus is passed from person to person by poor infection control,\" says Heymann.\n\nAs outbreaks are somewhat regular, health officials are still hopeful the current spike in infections will come to a natural end. \"From past experiences we expect numbers to start decreasing in March/April,\" says Nasidi.\n\n[Byline: Meera Senthilingam]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The number of Lassa fever deaths in Nigeria has increased from 63 as of week 7 (week ending 19 Feb 2016) to 130 reported above. The reason for the higher than usual number of fatal cases is undetermined. One possibility is an increase in the populations of multimammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.), with increase numbers of virus carriers, due to more favorable environmental conditions for them. This could result in more contamination of the environment with virus-containing excreta from these rodents. Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the home. Preventing entry of rodents into the home and keeping food materials tightly covered are helpful measures to prevent infection. Prevention and control of Lassa fever depend on control of the rodent reservoir, the multimammate mouse, which occurs across Nigeria and beyond. Reduction of populations of this rodent will require active participation at the village level.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (21): Nigeria (TA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4123464", "date": "2016-03-19 13:37:57", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (18): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Mar 2016\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/17/health/lassa-fever-outbreak-nigeria/index.html\n\n\nMore than 130 people are suspected to have died from a Lassa fever outbreak in Nigeria, according to statistics from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).\n\nThe disease can cause fever and haemorrhaging of various parts of the body -- including the eyes and nose -- and can spread through contact with an infected rat. Person to person transmission is also possible, albeit less common.\n\nFor people witnessing the symptoms, alarm bells may ring and raise fears of Ebola -- but this is not Ebola.\n\nWest Africa as a region is seeing a flare-up of the disease, but Nigeria -- where Lassa fever was first discovered in 1969 -- is experiencing much higher mortality rates than usual.\n\nOn average, Lassa fever is deadly in 1 percent of all individuals infected, with higher rates of 15 percent morbidity among people hospitalized for the illness, but the current outbreak in Nigeria has seen more than 50 percent of those affected dying from their infection.\n\nAccording to NCDC's latest report, dated 14 Mar 2016, the total number of reported cases is 254 (129 of which confirmed by lab tests) and the total number of deaths (suspected, probable and confirmed) is 137, with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 53.9 percent.\n\nA 2012 outbreak of Lassa fever in Nigeria caused more than 1700 people to become infected, but 112 deaths, according to the Nigerian Center for Disease Control (NCDC). Despite lower case numbers, the death toll in the current outbreak are already higher.\n\n\"The deaths among cases are higher than normal, and we are currently establishing the reason for this,\" says Abdulsalami Nasidi, Director of the NCDC.\n\nA further concern is the geographic spread of the outbreak: \"More states are affected (than usual), and we're evaluating possible reasons,\" says Nasidi.\n\nLassa fever outbreaks occur most years in West Africa, as the disease is endemic to Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and Nigeria.\n\nEach year, the virus infects an estimated 100 000-300 000 and is responsible for 5000 deaths in the region as a whole.\n\nLassa virus is in the same family of viruses as Ebola and Marburg virus, which also cause fever and sometimes haemorrhage. [This is not correct. Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus and Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses. - Mod.TY]. The virus is named after the Nigerian town of Lassa where it was first discovered.\n\nOutbreaks generally occur during the region's dry season -- typically between November to February -- but this time it's persisting. Officials are speculating on the reasons for the increased mortality and spread, but the truth remains unknown. \"Viruses change over time,\" says Nasidi.\n\nOne theory officials are suggesting for the spread of the virus into new states, is that there may be better awareness of symptoms after the 2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa, which has infected more than 28 000 people. Previously, infections often went unreported as the disease mainly affects rural areas where populations can be highly infected, but don't notify the authorities.\n\nThe main culprit behind the transmission of Lassa fever is the \"multimammate rat\" -- a reservoir for the virus with the ability to spread it to humans. Touching, consuming, or inhaling, the urine or feces of a rat carrying the virus is the prime route of infection in humans. This generally happens through contaminated food and surfaces within people's homes -- particularly during the dry season.\n\n\"When the rains are over, the rats then come closer to humans to steal grains,\" says David Heymann, Professor of Infectious Disease Epidemiology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. In rural areas, communities often store grains in their homes after the harvest to get them through the dry season. \"They [the rodents] urinate and defecate on the rice, which makes the uncooked rice a source of human infection,\" says Heymann. The meat of rodents is often eaten in the region, further increasing the likelihood of transmission.\n\nContact with the bodily fluids, or tissues, of another human carrying the virus is also a mode of transmission, but more rare.\n\nThe symptoms of the disease are wide-ranging and vary from mild to severe in different cases, making diagnosis a challenge.\n\nOne in 5 of those infected will experience symptoms including haemorrhage, respiratory problems, and facial swelling, especially if diagnosed late with the disease, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The remaining 80 percent experience much milder symptoms such as fever and weakness, which can often go undiagnosed. Up to 1/3 of people infected also risk losing their hearing.\n\nTreatment is available with the antiviral drug ribavirin, but this has its greatest effect if used early.\n\nThe NCDC and Ministry of Health have increased resources to handle the outbreak, such as mapping those at most risk, improving access to diagnostics and engaging with communities to recognize the signs and symptoms. \"Every life counts and every case must be investigated,\" says Nasidi.\n\nGiven the increased mortality, the priority is prevention. This includes reducing the chances of contact between humans and rat colonies.\n\nSales of rat poison in Nigeria have boomed since the outbreak was announced, according to reports by the news service AFP.\n\nAs with Ebola, awareness and increased use of personal protective equipment when handling patients is also crucial to prevent human to human transmission, particularly in health clinics. \"The government has made the right recommendations about infection control in health facilities...the virus is passed from person to person by poor infection control,\" says Heymann.\n\nAs outbreaks are somewhat regular, health officials are still hopeful the current spike in infections will come to a natural end. \"From past experiences we expect numbers to start decreasing in March/April,\" says Nasidi.\n\n[Byline: Meera Senthilingam]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The number of Lassa fever deaths in Nigeria has increased from 63 as of week 7 (week ending 19 Feb 2016) to 130 reported above. The reason for the higher than usual number of fatal cases is undetermined. One possibility is an increase in the populations of multimammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.), with increase numbers of virus carriers, due to more favorable environmental conditions for them. This could result in more contamination of the environment with virus-containing excreta from these rodents. Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the home. Preventing entry of rodents into the home and keeping food materials tightly covered are helpful measures to prevent infection. Prevention and control of Lassa fever depend on control of the rodent reservoir, the multimammate mouse, which occurs across Nigeria and beyond. Reduction of populations of this rodent will require active participation at the village level.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - West Africa (18): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4105938", "date": "2016-03-19 13:37:57", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (18): NIGERIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Mar 2016\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/17/health/lassa-fever-outbreak-nigeria/index.html\n\n\nMore than 130 people are suspected to have died from a Lassa fever outbreak in Nigeria, according to statistics from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).\n\nThe disease can cause fever and haemorrhaging of various parts of the body -- including the eyes and nose -- and can spread through contact with an infected rat. Person to person transmission is also possible, albeit less common.\n\nFor people witnessing the symptoms, alarm bells may ring and raise fears of Ebola -- but this is not Ebola.\n\nWest Africa as a region is seeing a flare-up of the disease, but Nigeria -- where Lassa fever was first discovered in 1969 -- is experiencing much higher mortality rates than usual.\n\nOn average, Lassa fever is deadly in 1 percent of all individuals infected, with higher rates of 15 percent morbidity among people hospitalized for the illness, but the current outbreak in Nigeria has seen more than 50 percent of those affected dying from their infection.\n\nAccording to NCDC's latest report, dated 14 Mar 2016, the total number of reported cases is 254 (129 of which confirmed by lab tests) and the total number of deaths (suspected, probable and confirmed) is 137, with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 53.9 percent.\n\nA 2012 outbreak of Lassa fever in Nigeria caused more than 1700 people to become infected, but 112 deaths, according to the Nigerian Center for Disease Control (NCDC). Despite lower case numbers, the death toll in the current outbreak are already higher.\n\n\"The deaths among cases are higher than normal, and we are currently establishing the reason for this,\" says Abdulsalami Nasidi, Director of the NCDC.\n\nA further concern is the geographic spread of the outbreak: \"More states are affected (than usual), and we're evaluating possible reasons,\" says Nasidi.\n\nLassa fever outbreaks occur most years in West Africa, as the disease is endemic to Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and Nigeria.\n\nEach year, the virus infects an estimated 100 000-300 000 and is responsible for 5000 deaths in the region as a whole.\n\nLassa virus is in the same family of viruses as Ebola and Marburg virus, which also cause fever and sometimes haemorrhage. [This is not correct. Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus and Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses. - Mod.TY]. The virus is named after the Nigerian town of Lassa where it was first discovered.\n\nOutbreaks generally occur during the region's dry season -- typically between November to February -- but this time it's persisting. Officials are speculating on the reasons for the increased mortality and spread, but the truth remains unknown. \"Viruses change over time,\" says Nasidi.\n\nOne theory officials are suggesting for the spread of the virus into new states, is that there may be better awareness of symptoms after the 2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa, which has infected more than 28 000 people. Previously, infections often went unreported as the disease mainly affects rural areas where populations can be highly infected, but don't notify the authorities.\n\nThe main culprit behind the transmission of Lassa fever is the \"multimammate rat\" -- a reservoir for the virus with the ability to spread it to humans. Touching, consuming, or inhaling, the urine or feces of a rat carrying the virus is the prime route of infection in humans. This generally happens through contaminated food and surfaces within people's homes -- particularly during the dry season.\n\n\"When the rains are over, the rats then come closer to humans to steal grains,\" says David Heymann, Professor of Infectious Disease Epidemiology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. In rural areas, communities often store grains in their homes after the harvest to get them through the dry season. \"They [the rodents] urinate and defecate on the rice, which makes the uncooked rice a source of human infection,\" says Heymann. The meat of rodents is often eaten in the region, further increasing the likelihood of transmission.\n\nContact with the bodily fluids, or tissues, of another human carrying the virus is also a mode of transmission, but more rare.\n\nThe symptoms of the disease are wide-ranging and vary from mild to severe in different cases, making diagnosis a challenge.\n\nOne in 5 of those infected will experience symptoms including haemorrhage, respiratory problems, and facial swelling, especially if diagnosed late with the disease, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The remaining 80 percent experience much milder symptoms such as fever and weakness, which can often go undiagnosed. Up to 1/3 of people infected also risk losing their hearing.\n\nTreatment is available with the antiviral drug ribavirin, but this has its greatest effect if used early.\n\nThe NCDC and Ministry of Health have increased resources to handle the outbreak, such as mapping those at most risk, improving access to diagnostics and engaging with communities to recognize the signs and symptoms. \"Every life counts and every case must be investigated,\" says Nasidi.\n\nGiven the increased mortality, the priority is prevention. This includes reducing the chances of contact between humans and rat colonies.\n\nSales of rat poison in Nigeria have boomed since the outbreak was announced, according to reports by the news service AFP.\n\nAs with Ebola, awareness and increased use of personal protective equipment when handling patients is also crucial to prevent human to human transmission, particularly in health clinics. \"The government has made the right recommendations about infection control in health facilities...the virus is passed from person to person by poor infection control,\" says Heymann.\n\nAs outbreaks are somewhat regular, health officials are still hopeful the current spike in infections will come to a natural end. \"From past experiences we expect numbers to start decreasing in March/April,\" says Nasidi.\n\n[Byline: Meera Senthilingam]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The number of Lassa fever deaths in Nigeria has increased from 63 as of week 7 (week ending 19 Feb 2016) to 130 reported above. The reason for the higher than usual number of fatal cases is undetermined. One possibility is an increase in the populations of multimammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.), with increase numbers of virus carriers, due to more favorable environmental conditions for them. This could result in more contamination of the environment with virus-containing excreta from these rodents. Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the home. Preventing entry of rodents into the home and keeping food materials tightly covered are helpful measures to prevent infection. Prevention and control of Lassa fever depend on control of the rodent reservoir, the multimammate mouse, which occurs across Nigeria and beyond. Reduction of populations of this rodent will require active participation at the village level.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.) as was likely the case of the infected pregnant woman. Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection-control measures, as apparently was the case with the physician and the nurse. Because there can be person-to-person transmission via contact with viremic blood or secretions of infected patients, adequate patient isolation and use of personal protection equipment for treatment of infected patients is essential for safety. Unfortunately, nosocomial transmission is not unusual.\n\nPrevention and control of Lassa fever in nature depend on control of the rodent reservoir, the multimammate mouse (_Mastomys_ spp.), which occurs across Nigeria and beyond. Reduction of populations of this rodent will require active participation at the village level. That will necessitate mounting a public education program with support of rodent control technicians. Because there can be person-to-person transmission via contact with viremic blood or secretions of infected patients, adequate patient isolation and use of personal protection equipment for treatment of infected patients is essential for safety. Unfortunately, nosocomial transmission is not unusual.\n\nPrevention and control of Lassa fever in nature depend on control of the rodent reservoir, the multimammate mouse (_Mastomys_ spp.), which occurs across Nigeria and beyond. Reduction of populations of this rodent will require active participation at the village level. That will necessitate mounting a public education program with support of rodent control technicians. There has been no indication that a village-level control effort has been initiated yet.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2341. - Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses, and Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus].\n\nIts name is from the town of Lassa in northern Nigeria where it was initially identified in 1969.\n\nEndemic to the region, Lassa fever is asymptomatic in 80 percent of cases but for others it can cause internal bleeding, especially when diagnosed late.\n\nThe virus is spread through contact with food or household items contaminated with rats' urine or faeces or after coming in direct contact with the bodily fluids of an infected person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in Lassa fever cases in Benin is of concern. Because there can be person-to-person transmission via contact with viremic blood or secretions of infected patients, adequate patient isolation and use of personal protection equipment for treatment of infected patients is essential for safety.\n\nThe circumstances under which the Lassa fever patients in Benin acquired their Lassa fever virus infections are not stated.\n\nThis is now the 5th report of Lassa fever that ProMED-mail has posted for Benin recently; the previous 3 occurred during an outbreak in 2014-2015.\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate rats (_Mastomys_ spp). Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the hoime. Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection control measures.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin can be accessed at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/benin/beu51k8n/benin_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22157. - West Africa (08): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4039559", "date": "2016-02-06 18:54:55", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (02): BENIN\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Feb 2016\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttp://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/nine-people-suspected-dead-of-lassa-fever-in-benin-116020300052_1.html\n\n\nAs the world ramps up its fight against the Zika virus, West Africa is battling to contain a growing outbreak of Lassa fever with 9 people in Benin reported dead. \"Right now, there are a total of 20 suspected cases with 9 deaths,\" government health official Orou Bagou Yorou Chabi said.\n\nThe 1st Lassa fever case in the West African country of 10 million people was listed at the Hospital of St Martin de Papane, in Tchaourou, a city 350 km (220 miles) north of Cotonou [Benin's largest city, pop. about 1 million], the United Nations children agency UNICEF said in a statement.\n\nAn ongoing epidemic in neighbouring Nigeria has already killed 84 people, out of 168 suspected cases, according to UNICEF.\n\nStocks of Ribavirin, a drug used to treat the infection, were being shipped to Tchaourou and Cotonou, the UN agency added.\n\nBenin was last hit by a Lassa fever outbreak in October 2014, when 9 people suspected of having the virus died.\n\nLassa fever belongs to the same family as Marburg and Ebola, 2 deadly viruses that lead to infections with fever, vomiting and, in worse-case scenarios, haemorrhagic bleeding [these viruses are clinically known as hemorrhagic fever viruses but are in very different families. Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses, and Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus].\n\nIts name is from the town of Lassa in northern Nigeria where it was initially identified in 1969.\n\nEndemic to the region, Lassa fever is asymptomatic in 80 percent of cases but for others it can cause internal bleeding, especially when diagnosed late.\n\nThe virus is spread through contact with food or household items contaminated with rats' urine or faeces or after coming in direct contact with the bodily fluids of an infected person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in Lassa fever cases in Benin is of concern. Because there can be person-to-person transmission via contact with viremic blood or secretions of infected patients, adequate patient isolation and use of personal protection equipment for treatment of infected patients is essential for safety.\n\nThe circumstances under which the Lassa fever patients in Benin acquired their Lassa fever virus infections are not stated.\n\nThis is now the 5th report of Lassa fever that ProMED-mail has posted for Benin recently; the previous 3 occurred during an outbreak in 2014-2015.\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate rats (_Mastomys_ spp). Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the hoime. Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection control measures.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin can be accessed at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/benin/beu51k8n/benin_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22157. - West Africa (03): Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4002672", "date": "2016-02-06 18:54:55", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (02): BENIN\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Feb 2016\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttp://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/nine-people-suspected-dead-of-lassa-fever-in-benin-116020300052_1.html\n\n\nAs the world ramps up its fight against the Zika virus, West Africa is battling to contain a growing outbreak of Lassa fever with 9 people in Benin reported dead. \"Right now, there are a total of 20 suspected cases with 9 deaths,\" government health official Orou Bagou Yorou Chabi said.\n\nThe 1st Lassa fever case in the West African country of 10 million people was listed at the Hospital of St Martin de Papane, in Tchaourou, a city 350 km (220 miles) north of Cotonou [Benin's largest city, pop. about 1 million], the United Nations children agency UNICEF said in a statement.\n\nAn ongoing epidemic in neighbouring Nigeria has already killed 84 people, out of 168 suspected cases, according to UNICEF.\n\nStocks of Ribavirin, a drug used to treat the infection, were being shipped to Tchaourou and Cotonou, the UN agency added.\n\nBenin was last hit by a Lassa fever outbreak in October 2014, when 9 people suspected of having the virus died.\n\nLassa fever belongs to the same family as Marburg and Ebola, 2 deadly viruses that lead to infections with fever, vomiting and, in worse-case scenarios, haemorrhagic bleeding [these viruses are clinically known as hemorrhagic fever viruses but are in very different families. Ebola and Marburg viruses are filoviruses, and Lassa fever virus is an arenavirus].\n\nIts name is from the town of Lassa in northern Nigeria where it was initially identified in 1969.\n\nEndemic to the region, Lassa fever is asymptomatic in 80 percent of cases but for others it can cause internal bleeding, especially when diagnosed late.\n\nThe virus is spread through contact with food or household items contaminated with rats' urine or faeces or after coming in direct contact with the bodily fluids of an infected person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The increase in Lassa fever cases in Benin is of concern. Because there can be person-to-person transmission via contact with viremic blood or secretions of infected patients, adequate patient isolation and use of personal protection equipment for treatment of infected patients is essential for safety.\n\nThe circumstances under which the Lassa fever patients in Benin acquired their Lassa fever virus infections are not stated.\n\nThis is now the 5th report of Lassa fever that ProMED-mail has posted for Benin recently; the previous 3 occurred during an outbreak in 2014-2015.\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate rats (_Mastomys_ spp). Public education is an important measure to prevent infections in the hoime. Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection control measures.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin can be accessed at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/benin/beu51k8n/benin_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22157. - West Africa: Nigeria, Benin", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3980796", "date": "2016-01-06 17:58:39", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (03): (RIVERS)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jan 2016\nSource: Vanguard [edited]\nhttp://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/01/lassa-fever-kills-mother-2-week-old-baby-in-rivers/\n\n\nA mother and her 2-week-old baby have been confirmed dead following a recent outbreak of Lassa fever in Rivers State.\n\nVanguard gathered that the woman lost her life on 30 Dec 2015 after successfully giving birth through caesarean, while the baby later died on 1 Jan [2016], having contracted the deadly Viral Hemorrhagic Disease from her late mother.\n\nConfirming the deaths, the Rivers State Commissioner of Health, Dr. Theophilus Odagme, said when the symptoms of Lassa Fever were noticed in the dead woman that experts in the Department of Microbiology, University of Port Harcourt were consulted and samples from her were also sent to a Specialist Centre in Lagos where it was confirmed that it was the dreaded ailment.\n\nOdegma disclosed that contact tracing of the people who are infected with the disease has begun, adding that the state government has geared up efforts to stop the spread and further death.\n\nOdegma said: \"The public is hereby assured that the government is on top of the matter and is doing everything to address the situation as the state government, World Health Organization and other partners and stakeholders are working tirelessly to address the outbreak adequately. The public is encouraged not to panic but report to the nearest hospital or Health Centre if they experience symptoms such as persistent high fever, stooling, vomiting and bleeding from the nose, mouth and anus.\"\n\nHe warned: \"Lassa fever is highly contagious and easily transmitted by rodents and direct contact with infected blood, urine or faeces, so people are advised to improve on the sanitation of their environment to prevent contact with the rat.\"\n\n[Byline: Davies Iheamnachor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were no Lassa fever cases reported in Rivers state in 2015. The latest Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Nigeria Federal Ministry of Health Bulletin No. 5 (44) issued on 6 Nov 2015 indicated that Lassa fever cases were reported in 12 states in Nigeria in 2015 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20151125.3819446). Lassa fever virus [LFV] is endemic in Nigeria, and multi-mammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.) are the rodent hosts. Lassa fever is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country.\n\nLFV can be transmitted from person to person through contact with an infected individual's viremic blood in the absence of adequate personal protective equipment. Several cases of transmission have occurred in hospitals. Fortunately, there were no cases among the Kano AKTH staff in the previous ProMED-mail report.\n\nAs the late Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived posting 20130131.1524034: \"In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multisystem disease. Rarely, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\"\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contact with food or household items contaminated with excreta of the reservoir rodent host. In the absence of adequate infection control measures, person-to-person virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments, or in laboratories testing samples from patients.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nA map of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3038. - Nigeria (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3959273", "date": "2016-01-06 17:58:39", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (03): (RIVERS)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jan 2016\nSource: Vanguard [edited]\nhttp://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/01/lassa-fever-kills-mother-2-week-old-baby-in-rivers/\n\n\nA mother and her 2-week-old baby have been confirmed dead following a recent outbreak of Lassa fever in Rivers State.\n\nVanguard gathered that the woman lost her life on 30 Dec 2015 after successfully giving birth through caesarean, while the baby later died on 1 Jan [2016], having contracted the deadly Viral Hemorrhagic Disease from her late mother.\n\nConfirming the deaths, the Rivers State Commissioner of Health, Dr. Theophilus Odagme, said when the symptoms of Lassa Fever were noticed in the dead woman that experts in the Department of Microbiology, University of Port Harcourt were consulted and samples from her were also sent to a Specialist Centre in Lagos where it was confirmed that it was the dreaded ailment.\n\nOdegma disclosed that contact tracing of the people who are infected with the disease has begun, adding that the state government has geared up efforts to stop the spread and further death.\n\nOdegma said: \"The public is hereby assured that the government is on top of the matter and is doing everything to address the situation as the state government, World Health Organization and other partners and stakeholders are working tirelessly to address the outbreak adequately. The public is encouraged not to panic but report to the nearest hospital or Health Centre if they experience symptoms such as persistent high fever, stooling, vomiting and bleeding from the nose, mouth and anus.\"\n\nHe warned: \"Lassa fever is highly contagious and easily transmitted by rodents and direct contact with infected blood, urine or faeces, so people are advised to improve on the sanitation of their environment to prevent contact with the rat.\"\n\n[Byline: Davies Iheamnachor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There were no Lassa fever cases reported in Rivers state in 2015. The latest Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Nigeria Federal Ministry of Health Bulletin No. 5 (44) issued on 6 Nov 2015 indicated that Lassa fever cases were reported in 12 states in Nigeria in 2015 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20151125.3819446). Lassa fever virus [LFV] is endemic in Nigeria, and multi-mammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.) are the rodent hosts. Lassa fever is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country.\n\nLFV can be transmitted from person to person through contact with an infected individual's viremic blood in the absence of adequate personal protective equipment. Several cases of transmission have occurred in hospitals. Fortunately, there were no cases among the Kano AKTH staff in the previous ProMED-mail report.\n\nAs the late Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived posting 20130131.1524034: \"In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multisystem disease. Rarely, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\"\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contact with food or household items contaminated with excreta of the reservoir rodent host. In the absence of adequate infection control measures, person-to-person virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments, or in laboratories testing samples from patients.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nA map of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3038. - As noted in the comments in ProMED-mail archive no. 20150228.3199551: \"Lassa fever virus [LFV] is endemic in Nigeria and multi-mammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.) are the rodent hosts. Lassa fever is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country.\" LFV can be transmitted from person to person through contact with an infected individual's viremic blood in the absence of adequate personal protective equipment. Several cases of transmission have occurred in hospitals.\n\nAs Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived report 20130131.1524034: \"In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multi-system disease. Rarely, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\"\n\n\"The virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contact with food or household items contaminated with excreta of the reservoir rodent host. In the absence of adequate infection control measures, person-to-person virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments, or in laboratories testing samples from patients.\"\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Nigerian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Lassa fever is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country.\" LFV can be transmitted from person to person through contact with an infected individual's viremic blood in the absence of adequate personal protective equipment. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multi-system disease. Rarely, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\"\n\n\"The virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contact with food or household items contaminated with excreta of the reservoir rodent host. In the absence of adequate infection control measures, person-to-person virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments, or in laboratories testing samples from patients.\"\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Nigerian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - BENIN: (ATAKORA)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Nov 2014\nSource: MedicalXpress (AP) [edited]\nhttp://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-11-dead-ebola-like-lassa-fever-benin.html\n\n\nThe Benin government and a World Health Organization (WHO) official said on [Fri 21 Nov 2014] that 2 people have died in the country from the Ebola-like virus Lassa fever. \"After samples were taken and testing, the results came back positive for Lassa fever, which is similar to the Ebola virus but not as virulent,\" public health minister Dorothee Akoko Kinde-Gazard said.\n\n[The symptoms are similar but the virus is in a different family and the case fatality rate is much lower. Ebola was excluded, see: Ebola virus disease - West Africa (213): Sierra Leone, Benin false alarm, Mali 20141118.2966829. - Mod.JW]\n\nThe 2 people were among 5 health workers who died at a hospital in Tanguieta [Atakora department], in the north of the tiny West African nation, which borders Nigeria to the west. \"There were 5 deaths at the hospital in Tanguieta but from the samples taken only 2 were positive (for Lassa fever),\" she told AFP [Agence France-Presse]. Gazard said that \"no other case has yet been brought to our attention\". The WHO's representative in the country, Youssouf Gamatie, was quoted as saying in the Benin media: \"It's lucky that we have detected it in the initial phase.\" Benin's authorities said they were expecting additional medication to deal with any further cases.\n\nAccording to the WHO, Lassa fever is an acute haemorrhagic illness [caused by a virus] which belongs to the arenavirus family of viruses, which also includes the Ebola-like _Marburgvirus_. [This statement about _Marburgvirus_ is incorrect. _Marburgvirus_ belongs to the filovirus family, as does _Ebolavirus_. - Mod.TY]. It was 1st identified in 1969 in the north Nigerian town of the same name.\n\nThe virus, which is endemic in rodents in West Africa, is transmitted to humans by contact with food or household items contaminated with the animals' faeces and urine. Person-to-person contact is also possible through bodily fluids, particularly in hospitals when adequate infection control measures are not taken.\n\nPeople with Lassa fever do not display symptoms in 80 percent of cases but it can cause serious symptoms and death in the remainder.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the number of Lassa fever infections in west Africa every year is between\n100 000-300 000, with about 5000 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although this is the 1st report of Lassa fever that ProMED-mail has posted for Benin, the occurrence is not surprising. Benin adjoins Nigeria in West Africa. As noted in the 2014 ProMED-mail post on Lassa fever in Nigeria cited below, Lassa fever virus is endemic in Nigeria and is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country. It is safe to assume that Lassa fever virus is also endemic in Benin. As Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived post 20130131.1524034: \"In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multi-system disease. Exceptionally, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality ratio can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\" Unfortunately, transmission occurs all to frequently in hospitals with inadequate isolation and personal protection for medical staff.\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate rats (_Mastomys_ spp.). Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection control measures. Because elimination of these rodents is not possible currently, reduction of risk of human infections can be accomplished, but eradication of the virus in these endemic areas cannot.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin in West Africa can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Benin.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42810. - Nigeria (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3322978", "date": "2014-11-24 07:33:38", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - BENIN: (ATAKORA)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Nov 2014\nSource: MedicalXpress (AP) [edited]\nhttp://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-11-dead-ebola-like-lassa-fever-benin.html\n\n\nThe Benin government and a World Health Organization (WHO) official said on [Fri 21 Nov 2014] that 2 people have died in the country from the Ebola-like virus Lassa fever. \"After samples were taken and testing, the results came back positive for Lassa fever, which is similar to the Ebola virus but not as virulent,\" public health minister Dorothee Akoko Kinde-Gazard said.\n\n[The symptoms are similar but the virus is in a different family and the case fatality rate is much lower. Ebola was excluded, see: Ebola virus disease - West Africa (213): Sierra Leone, Benin false alarm, Mali 20141118.2966829. - Mod.JW]\n\nThe 2 people were among 5 health workers who died at a hospital in Tanguieta [Atakora department], in the north of the tiny West African nation, which borders Nigeria to the west. \"There were 5 deaths at the hospital in Tanguieta but from the samples taken only 2 were positive (for Lassa fever),\" she told AFP [Agence France-Presse]. Gazard said that \"no other case has yet been brought to our attention\". The WHO's representative in the country, Youssouf Gamatie, was quoted as saying in the Benin media: \"It's lucky that we have detected it in the initial phase.\" Benin's authorities said they were expecting additional medication to deal with any further cases.\n\nAccording to the WHO, Lassa fever is an acute haemorrhagic illness [caused by a virus] which belongs to the arenavirus family of viruses, which also includes the Ebola-like _Marburgvirus_. [This statement about _Marburgvirus_ is incorrect. _Marburgvirus_ belongs to the filovirus family, as does _Ebolavirus_. - Mod.TY]. It was 1st identified in 1969 in the north Nigerian town of the same name.\n\nThe virus, which is endemic in rodents in West Africa, is transmitted to humans by contact with food or household items contaminated with the animals' faeces and urine. Person-to-person contact is also possible through bodily fluids, particularly in hospitals when adequate infection control measures are not taken.\n\nPeople with Lassa fever do not display symptoms in 80 percent of cases but it can cause serious symptoms and death in the remainder.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that the number of Lassa fever infections in west Africa every year is between\n100 000-300 000, with about 5000 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although this is the 1st report of Lassa fever that ProMED-mail has posted for Benin, the occurrence is not surprising. Benin adjoins Nigeria in West Africa. As noted in the 2014 ProMED-mail post on Lassa fever in Nigeria cited below, Lassa fever virus is endemic in Nigeria and is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country. It is safe to assume that Lassa fever virus is also endemic in Benin. As Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived post 20130131.1524034: \"In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multi-system disease. Exceptionally, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality ratio can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients.\" Unfortunately, transmission occurs all to frequently in hospitals with inadequate isolation and personal protection for medical staff.\n\nThe virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contacts with food or household items contaminated with excreta of multimammate rats (_Mastomys_ spp.). Virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments or laboratories in the absence of adequate infection control measures. Because elimination of these rodents is not possible currently, reduction of risk of human infections can be accomplished, but eradication of the virus in these endemic areas cannot.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin in West Africa can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Benin.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42810. - Because elimination of these rodents is not possible currently, reduction of risk of human infections can be accomplished, but eradication of the virus in these endemic areas cannot.\n\nImages of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.\n\nMaps of Benin in West Africa can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Benin.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42810. - Mod.TY\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (08): (OY) 20141028.2909777\nLassa fever - USA ex West Africa 20140405.2382486\nLassa fever - Nigeria, Liberia 20140328.2363217\n2013\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (12): (EB) nosocomial 20131030.2030154\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "lassa fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "lassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "EB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2909777", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - Nigeria (08): (OY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2909777", "date": "2014-03-28 20:56:18", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA, LIBERIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Mar 2014\nSource: WHO Outbreak Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.afro.who.int/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=9154&Itemid=2593\n\n\nLassa Fever in Nigeria\n----------------------\nNigeria continues to experience an outbreak of Lassa fever in different parts of the country. From 1 Jan 2014 to 16 Mar 2014, a total of 208 cases including 17 deaths (CFR: 8.2 per cent) were reported from 19 LGAs [Local Government Areas] within 9 states as shown in figures 6 & 7 [see the source URL]; 83 per cent (173/208) of the cases were reported from Edo state. A total of 27 cases were laboratory confirmed.\n\nDuring 2012 and 2013, a total of 1723 suspected cases including 112 deaths (CFR 6.5 per cent) and 1195 cases including 39 deaths (CFR 3.3 per cent) were reported respectively.\n\nThe Federal and State governments with support from WHO and other partners are responding to the outbreak by reinforcing active surveillance and public enlightenment; and sensitizing clinicians on case management protocol and Standard precautions, among others.\n\nLassa Fever in Liberia\n----------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MOH) of Liberia has notified WHO of an outbreak of Lassa fever in a UN Mission in Liberia Kakata camp, Margibi County. A total of 14 cases including one death were reported from 27 Feb 2014 to 10 Mar 2014. A total of 11 of the cases had been reported among UN Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) Kakata camp peace keepers, 2 among UNMIL civil/UNPOL [United Nations Police] in the camp, while one case is from the neighboring community related to cases in the camp. All the 14 cases have been laboratory confirmed to be due to Lassa fever. Although Lassa fever is endemic in Liberia and occurring as sporadic cases in Bong, Nimba and Lofa counties, this is the 1st time a case has been reported in Margibi County which is close to Montserrado County where the national capital city, Monrovia is located.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever virus is endemic in Nigeria. This is the 4th report of cases of Lassa fever virus for Nigeria in 2014 that ProMED-mail has posted. Cases have occurred sporadically in Liberia and this is the 1st report for 2014. Mod.CP provided an excellent summary of Lassa fever (ProMED-mail archive no. 20130911.1937742): \"Lassa fever is an acute viral illness that occurs in West Africa. The cause of the illness was found to be Lassa virus, named after the town in Nigeria where the 1st cases originated. The virus, a member of the virus family _Arenaviridae_, is a single-stranded RNA virus and is zoonotic, or animal-borne. Lassa fever is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever is mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 percent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 percent have a severe multisystem disease. Lassa fever is an endemic disease in portions of West Africa. It is recognized in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone as well as Nigeria. However, because the rodent species which carry the virus are found throughout West Africa, the actual geographic range of the disease may extend to other countries in the region. Individuals at risk are those who live in or visit areas with a high population of _Mastomys_ rodents infected with Lassa virus or are exposed to infected humans.\n\n\"Primary transmission of the Lassa virus to humans can be prevented by avoiding contact with _Mastomys_ rodents, especially in the geographic regions where outbreaks occur. Storing food away in rodent-proof containers and keeping living areas clean help to discourage rodents from entering homes. When caring for patients with Lassa fever, further transmission of the disease through person-to-person contact or nosocomial routes can be avoided by taking preventive precautions against contact with patient secretions (together called VHF [viral hemorrhagic fever] isolation precautions or barrier nursing methods) [http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/vhfmanual.htm]. Such precautions include wearing protective clothing, such as masks, gloves, gowns, and goggles; using infection control measures, such as complete equipment sterilization; and isolating infected patients from contact with unprotected persons until the disease has run its course. The disease can be treated.\n\n\"Signs and symptoms of Lassa fever typically occur 1-3 weeks after the patient comes into contact with the virus. These include fever, retrosternal pain (pain behind the chest wall), sore throat, back pain, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, conjunctivitis, facial swelling, proteinuria (protein in the urine), and mucosal bleeding. Neurological problems have also been described, including hearing loss, tremors, and encephalitis. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and nonspecific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult. The anti-viral drug ribavirin can be used in treatment of severe cases. Currently, there is no protective vaccine.\"\n\nA HealthMap of Nigeria can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62 and of Liberia at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54. - Mod.TY\n\nThe 2-fold difference between the CFR in Nigeria for 2012 & 2013 could be explained by the possibility that a smaller proportion of the suspect cases in 2013 were actually Lassa fever, with the rest being due to other causes. It would be interesting to study the unconfirmed cases to discover what other diseases cause syndromes that are being reported as suspected Lassa. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03): (OY) 20140222.2294417\nLassa fever - Nigeria (05): (EB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2489540", "date": "2014-03-28 20:56:18", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA, LIBERIA\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Mar 2014\nSource: WHO Outbreak Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.afro.who.int/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=9154&Itemid=2593\n\n\nLassa Fever in Nigeria\n----------------------\nNigeria continues to experience an outbreak of Lassa fever in different parts of the country. From 1 Jan 2014 to 16 Mar 2014, a total of 208 cases including 17 deaths (CFR: 8.2 per cent) were reported from 19 LGAs [Local Government Areas] within 9 states as shown in figures 6 & 7 [see the source URL]; 83 per cent (173/208) of the cases were reported from Edo state. A total of 27 cases were laboratory confirmed.\n\nDuring 2012 and 2013, a total of 1723 suspected cases including 112 deaths (CFR 6.5 per cent) and 1195 cases including 39 deaths (CFR 3.3 per cent) were reported respectively.\n\nThe Federal and State governments with support from WHO and other partners are responding to the outbreak by reinforcing active surveillance and public enlightenment; and sensitizing clinicians on case management protocol and Standard precautions, among others.\n\nLassa Fever in Liberia\n----------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MOH) of Liberia has notified WHO of an outbreak of Lassa fever in a UN Mission in Liberia Kakata camp, Margibi County. A total of 14 cases including one death were reported from 27 Feb 2014 to 10 Mar 2014. A total of 11 of the cases had been reported among UN Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) Kakata camp peace keepers, 2 among UNMIL civil/UNPOL [United Nations Police] in the camp, while one case is from the neighboring community related to cases in the camp. All the 14 cases have been laboratory confirmed to be due to Lassa fever. Although Lassa fever is endemic in Liberia and occurring as sporadic cases in Bong, Nimba and Lofa counties, this is the 1st time a case has been reported in Margibi County which is close to Montserrado County where the national capital city, Monrovia is located.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever virus is endemic in Nigeria. This is the 4th report of cases of Lassa fever virus for Nigeria in 2014 that ProMED-mail has posted. Cases have occurred sporadically in Liberia and this is the 1st report for 2014. Mod.CP provided an excellent summary of Lassa fever (ProMED-mail archive no. 20130911.1937742): \"Lassa fever is an acute viral illness that occurs in West Africa. The cause of the illness was found to be Lassa virus, named after the town in Nigeria where the 1st cases originated. The virus, a member of the virus family _Arenaviridae_, is a single-stranded RNA virus and is zoonotic, or animal-borne. Lassa fever is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever is mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 percent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 percent have a severe multisystem disease. Lassa fever is an endemic disease in portions of West Africa. It is recognized in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone as well as Nigeria. However, because the rodent species which carry the virus are found throughout West Africa, the actual geographic range of the disease may extend to other countries in the region. Individuals at risk are those who live in or visit areas with a high population of _Mastomys_ rodents infected with Lassa virus or are exposed to infected humans.\n\n\"Primary transmission of the Lassa virus to humans can be prevented by avoiding contact with _Mastomys_ rodents, especially in the geographic regions where outbreaks occur. Storing food away in rodent-proof containers and keeping living areas clean help to discourage rodents from entering homes. When caring for patients with Lassa fever, further transmission of the disease through person-to-person contact or nosocomial routes can be avoided by taking preventive precautions against contact with patient secretions (together called VHF [viral hemorrhagic fever] isolation precautions or barrier nursing methods) [http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/vhfmanual.htm]. Such precautions include wearing protective clothing, such as masks, gloves, gowns, and goggles; using infection control measures, such as complete equipment sterilization; and isolating infected patients from contact with unprotected persons until the disease has run its course. The disease can be treated.\n\n\"Signs and symptoms of Lassa fever typically occur 1-3 weeks after the patient comes into contact with the virus. These include fever, retrosternal pain (pain behind the chest wall), sore throat, back pain, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, conjunctivitis, facial swelling, proteinuria (protein in the urine), and mucosal bleeding. Neurological problems have also been described, including hearing loss, tremors, and encephalitis. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and nonspecific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult. The anti-viral drug ribavirin can be used in treatment of severe cases. Currently, there is no protective vaccine.\"\n\nA HealthMap of Nigeria can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62 and of Liberia at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/54. - Mod.TY\n\nThe 2-fold difference between the CFR in Nigeria for 2012 & 2013 could be explained by the possibility that a smaller proportion of the suspect cases in 2013 were actually Lassa fever, with the rest being due to other causes. It would be interesting to study the unconfirmed cases to discover what other diseases cause syndromes that are being reported as suspected Lassa. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03): (OY) 20140222.2294417\nLassa fever - It would be interesting to study the unconfirmed cases to discover what other diseases cause syndromes that are being reported as suspected Lassa. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03): (OY) 20140222.2294417\nLassa fever - Alpha]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever virus (LFV) is endemic in West Africa, although ProMED-mail has not received reports of cases there since 2010. Lassa fever has not as yet been confirmed in these individuals. More information on the results of laboratory tests for LFV would be greatly appreciated.\n\nPresuming these individuals do have Lassa fever, it is not clear if these unfortunate victims acquired their LFV infections in the hospital or elsewhere, probably from environments contaminated by the multimammate rodent reservoir host. LFV infections are usually not fatal; some 80 per cent of human infections are asymptomatic. Non-fatal cases may have severe multisystem disease, where the virus affects several organs such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. The incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6 to 21 days. More detailed information can be accessed at http://www.who.int/csr/disease/lassafever/en/.\n\nA photograph of a _Mastomys_ multimammate rat can be viewed at http://ec.europa.eu/research/rtdinfo/special_inco/03/images/art07_02_3759.jpg.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sierra Leone is available at http://healthmap.org/r/8jOJ. - Mods.TY/MPP]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (04): (NO) 20101111.4104\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (03): (NO) 20101017.3770\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (02): (NO) 20101008.3662\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone: (NO) 20101001.3555\n.................................................sb/mpp/ty/je/mpp/ty/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "lassa fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gondama", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1926142", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - Sierra Leone: (SO), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1926142", "date": "2013-09-06 01:11:39", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - SIERRA LEONE: (SOUTHERN), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 31 Aug 2013\nSource: All Africa [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201309020391.html\n\n\nA report reaching Concord Times indicated that a number of staff of Medicine San Frontiers (MSF) have allegedly died of Lassa fever in the municipality of Bo [Southern Province].\n\nThe report stated that a nurse, driver and a community health officer, alongside her 2 children, lost their lives after being allegedly infected with the disease; Nigeria (09): (RI) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1614827", "date": "2013-01-28 16:49:42", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (02): (NASARAWA) FATAL\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 26 Jan 2013\nSource: AllAfrica, Daily Trust report [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201301280466.html\n\n\nAn out break of Lassa fever in Lafia, the capital of Nasarawa State, which was confirmed last week, has led to the death of at least one person who shuttled between Nasarawa's 2 biggest health facilities in the frantic search for attention.\n\nThe 2nd and 3rd cases involving a couple were confirmed last Friday [25 Jan 2013] after diagnoses conducted on the victims by a team of epidemiologists at the Dalhatu Araf Specialists Hospital (DASH) in Lafia, the Chief Medical Director (CMD), Dr Ahmed Yakubu Ashiki, told the Weekly Trust newspaper, yesterday [25 Jan 2013]. The 3 victims including the deceased, the Weekly Trust learnt, were neighbours in Tudun Gwandara, an over-populated and one of the dirtiest sections of the metropolis.\n\nDr Ashiki told Weekly Trust that the 2 victims are still on admission at his hospital, and are \"doing very well.\" He expressed hope that with the medication they are receiving, they will be out of the hospital hale and hearty. He confirmed that one other person also contacted the virus, but added that \"he is not with us; he was not hospitalized here.\"\n\nEnquires by the Weekly Trust showed that the 3rd patient, a male, could not secure admission at the DASH because of inadequacy of beds, following which he was advised to proceed to the Federal Medical Centre (FMC), in Keffi, about an hour and 40 minutes drive from Lafia. But sources said this hospital also did not have bed space for the patient, and had to advise him to seek medical attention elsewhere. He died eventually, shuttling between DASH and FMC.\n\nDr Emmanuel Akabe, State Commissioner for Health who confirmed the outbreak by telephone also informed the Weekly Trust that he has information that the 3rd victim died 3 days ago. He said the patient was first at DASH, but added that there was no bed space to accommodate him, following which the state hospital referred him to the Federal Government-owned health facility, in Keffi. The commissioner said reports available to him showed that the patient died 3 days ago, after he reached DASH, but refused to stay longer while arrangement for his bed was being made.\n\nJamilu Nagogo, head of the information unit at the FMC, confirmed that the patient was at the hospital for medical attention, just as he confirmed that he had no admission there because of lack of bed space.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever is an acute viral illness that occurs in West Africa. The illness was discovered in 1969 when 2 missionary nurses died in Nigeria, West Africa. The cause of the illness was found to be Lassa virus, named after the town in Nigeria where the 1st cases originated. Lassa fever virus, a member of the virus family _Arenaviridae_, is a single-stranded RNA virus and is zoonotic, or animal-borne. Lassa fever is mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 percent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 percent have a severe multisystem disease. Lassa fever is also associated with occasional epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 percent.\n\nThe reservoir, or host, of Lassa virus is a rodent known as the \"multimammate rat\" of the genus _Mastomys_ (see image at http://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fil:Mastomys_coucha.jpg.). It is not certain which species of _Mastomys_ are associated with Lassa; however, at least 2 species carry the virus in Sierra Leone. _Mastomys_ rodents breed very frequently, produce large numbers of offspring, and are numerous in the savannas and forests of West, Central, and East Africa. In addition, _Mastomys_ generally readily colonize human homes. Lassa fever may also spread through person-to-person contact. This type of transmission occurs when a person comes into contact with virus in the blood, tissue, secretions, or excretions of an individual infected with the Lassa virus.\n\nApproximately 15-20 percent of patients hospitalized for Lassa fever die from the illness. The death rates are particularly high for women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, and for fetuses, about 95 percent of which die in the uterus of infected pregnant mothers. However, overall only about one percent of infections with Lassa virus result in death. The antiviral ribavirin has been used with success in the treatment of Lassa fever patients. It is not stated in this report the nature of the treatment available in Nigerian hospitals.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive of Nigeria can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/50T5. A map showing the location of Lafia and the state of Nasarawa in central Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.ialnigeria.com/home/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=108&Itemid=128. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - However, overall only about one percent of infections with Lassa virus result in death. The antiviral ribavirin has been used with success in the treatment of Lassa fever patients.
