Nigeria (05): (PL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1534092", "date": "2013-01-28 16:49:42", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (02): (NASARAWA) FATAL\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 26 Jan 2013\nSource: AllAfrica, Daily Trust report [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201301280466.html\n\n\nAn out break of Lassa fever in Lafia, the capital of Nasarawa State, which was confirmed last week, has led to the death of at least one person who shuttled between Nasarawa's 2 biggest health facilities in the frantic search for attention.\n\nThe 2nd and 3rd cases involving a couple were confirmed last Friday [25 Jan 2013] after diagnoses conducted on the victims by a team of epidemiologists at the Dalhatu Araf Specialists Hospital (DASH) in Lafia, the Chief Medical Director (CMD), Dr Ahmed Yakubu Ashiki, told the Weekly Trust newspaper, yesterday [25 Jan 2013]. The 3 victims including the deceased, the Weekly Trust learnt, were neighbours in Tudun Gwandara, an over-populated and one of the dirtiest sections of the metropolis.\n\nDr Ashiki told Weekly Trust that the 2 victims are still on admission at his hospital, and are \"doing very well.\" He expressed hope that with the medication they are receiving, they will be out of the hospital hale and hearty. He confirmed that one other person also contacted the virus, but added that \"he is not with us; he was not hospitalized here.\"\n\nEnquires by the Weekly Trust showed that the 3rd patient, a male, could not secure admission at the DASH because of inadequacy of beds, following which he was advised to proceed to the Federal Medical Centre (FMC), in Keffi, about an hour and 40 minutes drive from Lafia. But sources said this hospital also did not have bed space for the patient, and had to advise him to seek medical attention elsewhere. He died eventually, shuttling between DASH and FMC.\n\nDr Emmanuel Akabe, State Commissioner for Health who confirmed the outbreak by telephone also informed the Weekly Trust that he has information that the 3rd victim died 3 days ago. He said the patient was first at DASH, but added that there was no bed space to accommodate him, following which the state hospital referred him to the Federal Government-owned health facility, in Keffi. The commissioner said reports available to him showed that the patient died 3 days ago, after he reached DASH, but refused to stay longer while arrangement for his bed was being made.\n\nJamilu Nagogo, head of the information unit at the FMC, confirmed that the patient was at the hospital for medical attention, just as he confirmed that he had no admission there because of lack of bed space.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever is an acute viral illness that occurs in West Africa. The illness was discovered in 1969 when 2 missionary nurses died in Nigeria, West Africa. The cause of the illness was found to be Lassa virus, named after the town in Nigeria where the 1st cases originated. Lassa fever virus, a member of the virus family _Arenaviridae_, is a single-stranded RNA virus and is zoonotic, or animal-borne. Lassa fever is mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 percent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 percent have a severe multisystem disease. Lassa fever is also associated with occasional epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 percent.\n\nThe reservoir, or host, of Lassa virus is a rodent known as the \"multimammate rat\" of the genus _Mastomys_ (see image at http://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fil:Mastomys_coucha.jpg.). It is not certain which species of _Mastomys_ are associated with Lassa; however, at least 2 species carry the virus in Sierra Leone. _Mastomys_ rodents breed very frequently, produce large numbers of offspring, and are numerous in the savannas and forests of West, Central, and East Africa. In addition, _Mastomys_ generally readily colonize human homes. Lassa fever may also spread through person-to-person contact. This type of transmission occurs when a person comes into contact with virus in the blood, tissue, secretions, or excretions of an individual infected with the Lassa virus.\n\nApproximately 15-20 percent of patients hospitalized for Lassa fever die from the illness. The death rates are particularly high for women in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, and for fetuses, about 95 percent of which die in the uterus of infected pregnant mothers. However, overall only about one percent of infections with Lassa virus result in death. The antiviral ribavirin has been used with success in the treatment of Lassa fever patients. It is not stated in this report the nature of the treatment available in Nigerian hospitals.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive of Nigeria can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/50T5. A map showing the location of Lafia and the state of Nasarawa in central Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.ialnigeria.com/home/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=108&Itemid=128. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (BE), nosocomial", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1503116", "date": "2012-02-11 15:47:53", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER- NIGERIA (03): (TARABA), FATALITIES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Nigerian Tribune [edited]\nhttp://tribune.com.ng/index.php/news/35804-lassa-fever-kills-7-in-taraba\n\n\nLassa fever kills 7 in Taraba\n-----------------------\nSeven people have reportedly died in Taraba State, following an outbreak of Lassa fever a couple of days ago. The state Commissioner for Health, Prince Mustapha Hamman Gabdo, confirmed this while briefing journalists in the state. The commissioner said 4 of the victims of the disease died at the Federal Medical Centre, Jalingo, one died at the Government House Clinic, Jalingo, and the 2 others, who contracted the disease in Taraba State died in Gombe State after travelling there for treatment. He said the ministry had already taken measures to stop the spread of the epidemic and would embark on sensitisation campaigns as well as vaccinate the entire people of the state against the disease. [Vaccine not yet available. - Mod.CP]\n\nShedding more light on the source of the dreaded fever and its dangers to human beings, the head of Epidemiology unit in the state Ministry of Health, Innocent Vakai, said the disease was transmitted by a specific rat which had no hair on its tail [The multimamate rat -- _Mastonomys_]. The Epidemiologist said the symptoms of Lassa Fever included severe headache, high fever, vomiting that passed through all the openings in the human body, just as he advised persons having such symptoms to rush to the nearest hospital for medical attention.\n\nSimilary, the Taraba State House of Assembly, on Thursday [9 Feb 2012], summoned an urgent public importance sitting, following reported cases of outbreak of Lassa fever in Jalingo, the state capital.\n\nThe Member representing Gembu Constituency, Honorable Abubakar Jugidda, who disclosed this before the assembly, stressed the need for the state government to look into the issue immediately to control the epidemic to save lives. The law maker urged the house to impress on the state government to direct the Ministry of Health to provide the necessary drugs to the victims of the disease. He also advised the house to embark on an enlightenment campaign to educate the people of the danger of the diseases and ways of preventing same. Other members who commented on the issue, seconded the motion describing the disease as a dangerious thing to mankind that needed urgent attention.\n\nMembers, Mark Useni, Josiah Sabo Kente and Abubakar Lawal regretted the alarming rate the disease was claiming lives within and outside the state and urged the state government to take proactive step to address the issue.\n\n[Byline: Celestine Ihejirika]\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family _Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria, but probably exists in other West African countries as well. This is the 1st recent report of Lassa fever in Taraba state. So far 2 other outbreaks of Lassa fever been reported in Rivers state and Ebonyi state, also in southern of Nigeria.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen and kidneys. Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the \"multimammate rat\". _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta.\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women. Persons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where Mastomys are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper barrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and non-specific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult, especially early in the course of the disease. Lassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases which cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. Contrary to the statement in the above press report, no vaccine is available present.\n\nA map of Nigeria showing the locations of the 3 states (Ebonyi, Rivers and Taraba) reporting outbreaks of Lassa fever so far in 2012 can be accessed at: http://www.waado.org/nigerdelta/Maps/Nigeria_States.html.\n\nImages of a multimammate rats scan be viewed at: http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=multimammate+rat&hl=en&prmd=imvnsb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=TMk2T_mzGIfI0QWb06G_Ag&sqi=2&ved=0CFMQsAQ&biw=839&bih=386. - Lassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases which cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. Contrary to the statement in the above press report, no vaccine is available present.\n\nA map of Nigeria showing the locations of the 3 states (Ebonyi, Rivers and Taraba) reporting outbreaks of Lassa fever so far in 2012 can be accessed at: http://www.waado.org/nigerdelta/Maps/Nigeria_States.html.\n\nImages of a multimammate rats scan be viewed at: http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=multimammate+rat&hl=en&prmd=imvnsb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=TMk2T_mzGIfI0QWb06G_Ag&sqi=2&ved=0CFMQsAQ&biw=839&bih=386. - Nigeria (06) travel alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1117076", "date": "2012-02-11 15:47:53", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER- NIGERIA (03): (TARABA), FATALITIES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Nigerian Tribune [edited]\nhttp://tribune.com.ng/index.php/news/35804-lassa-fever-kills-7-in-taraba\n\n\nLassa fever kills 7 in Taraba\n-----------------------\nSeven people have reportedly died in Taraba State, following an outbreak of Lassa fever a couple of days ago. The state Commissioner for Health, Prince Mustapha Hamman Gabdo, confirmed this while briefing journalists in the state. The commissioner said 4 of the victims of the disease died at the Federal Medical Centre, Jalingo, one died at the Government House Clinic, Jalingo, and the 2 others, who contracted the disease in Taraba State died in Gombe State after travelling there for treatment. He said the ministry had already taken measures to stop the spread of the epidemic and would embark on sensitisation campaigns as well as vaccinate the entire people of the state against the disease. [Vaccine not yet available. - Mod.CP]\n\nShedding more light on the source of the dreaded fever and its dangers to human beings, the head of Epidemiology unit in the state Ministry of Health, Innocent Vakai, said the disease was transmitted by a specific rat which had no hair on its tail [The multimamate rat -- _Mastonomys_]. The Epidemiologist said the symptoms of Lassa Fever included severe headache, high fever, vomiting that passed through all the openings in the human body, just as he advised persons having such symptoms to rush to the nearest hospital for medical attention.\n\nSimilary, the Taraba State House of Assembly, on Thursday [9 Feb 2012], summoned an urgent public importance sitting, following reported cases of outbreak of Lassa fever in Jalingo, the state capital.\n\nThe Member representing Gembu Constituency, Honorable Abubakar Jugidda, who disclosed this before the assembly, stressed the need for the state government to look into the issue immediately to control the epidemic to save lives. The law maker urged the house to impress on the state government to direct the Ministry of Health to provide the necessary drugs to the victims of the disease. He also advised the house to embark on an enlightenment campaign to educate the people of the danger of the diseases and ways of preventing same. Other members who commented on the issue, seconded the motion describing the disease as a dangerious thing to mankind that needed urgent attention.\n\nMembers, Mark Useni, Josiah Sabo Kente and Abubakar Lawal regretted the alarming rate the disease was claiming lives within and outside the state and urged the state government to take proactive step to address the issue.\n\n[Byline: Celestine Ihejirika]\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family _Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria, but probably exists in other West African countries as well. This is the 1st recent report of Lassa fever in Taraba state. So far 2 other outbreaks of Lassa fever been reported in Rivers state and Ebonyi state, also in southern of Nigeria.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen and kidneys. Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the \"multimammate rat\". _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta.\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women. Persons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where Mastomys are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper barrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and non-specific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult, especially early in the course of the disease. Lassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases which cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. Contrary to the statement in the above press report, no vaccine is available present.\n\nA map of Nigeria showing the locations of the 3 states (Ebonyi, Rivers and Taraba) reporting outbreaks of Lassa fever so far in 2012 can be accessed at: http://www.waado.org/nigerdelta/Maps/Nigeria_States.html.\n\nImages of a multimammate rats scan be viewed at: http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=multimammate+rat&hl=en&prmd=imvnsb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=TMk2T_mzGIfI0QWb06G_Ag&sqi=2&ved=0CFMQsAQ&biw=839&bih=386. - The Epidemiologist said the symptoms of Lassa Fever included severe headache, high fever, vomiting that passed through all the openings in the human body, just as he advised persons having such symptoms to rush to the nearest hospital for medical attention.\n\nSimilary, the Taraba State House of Assembly, on Thursday [9 Feb 2012], summoned an urgent public importance sitting, following reported cases of outbreak of Lassa fever in Jalingo, the state capital.\n\nThe Member representing Gembu Constituency, Honorable Abubakar Jugidda, who disclosed this before the assembly, stressed the need for the state government to look into the issue immediately to control the epidemic to save lives. The law maker urged the house to impress on the state government to direct the Ministry of Health to provide the necessary drugs to the victims of the disease. He also advised the house to embark on an enlightenment campaign to educate the people of the danger of the diseases and ways of preventing same. Other members who commented on the issue, seconded the motion describing the disease as a dangerious thing to mankind that needed urgent attention.\n\nMembers, Mark Useni, Josiah Sabo Kente and Abubakar Lawal regretted the alarming rate the disease was claiming lives within and outside the state and urged the state government to take proactive step to address the issue.\n\n[Byline: Celestine Ihejirika]\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family _Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria, but probably exists in other West African countries as well. This is the 1st recent report of Lassa fever in Taraba state. So far 2 other outbreaks of Lassa fever been reported in Rivers state and Ebonyi state, also in southern of Nigeria.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen and kidneys. Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the \"multimammate rat\". _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta.\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women. Persons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where Mastomys are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper barrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and non-specific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult, especially early in the course of the disease. Lassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases which cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. Contrary to the statement in the above press report, no vaccine is available present.\n\nA map of Nigeria showing the locations of the 3 states (Ebonyi, Rivers and Taraba) reporting outbreaks of Lassa fever so far in 2012 can be accessed at: http://www.waado.org/nigerdelta/Maps/Nigeria_States.html.\n\nImages of a multimammate rats scan be viewed at: http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=multimammate+rat&hl=en&prmd=imvnsb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=TMk2T_mzGIfI0QWb06G_Ag&sqi=2&ved=0CFMQsAQ&biw=839&bih=386. - The virus is spread through contact with rat urine or faeces and\nlater between humans through contact with bodily secretions.\n\nTwo people died in October [2010] in Makeni, including a woman (who ran a\nrestaurant selling rat meat) and her 6 year old son.\n\nOf the 153 cases recorded nationwide in the 1st 10 months of the year, 48\npeople have died, according to health officials.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n[This report records another fatal case of Lassa fever in the vicinity of\nthe village of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. More than 51 million Nigerians\nare at risk, with the annual number of illnesses estimated at 3\nmillion and with the number of deaths estimated at about 58 330.\n\nThis disclosure came as the Guild of Medical Directors yesterday [18\nMar 2009] in Abuja demanded an adequate supply of Ribavirin (the\nantiviral drug for the treatment of Lassa fever) in the Federal\nCapital Territory (FCT) and its environs. Chief Medical Director of\nthe Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital, Irrua Edo State, Prof. George\nAkpede, made the disclosure yesterday on the occasion of the\ncommissioning of the Lassa Fever Diagnostic and Research Laboratory,\nInstitute of Lassa Fever Research and Control at the Irrua\nSpecialists Teaching Hospital, Irrua, Edo State. He said the Lassa\nfever epidemic was no longer limited to some states as it was thought\nbut had assumed virtually a country-wide dimension.\n\nThe outbreak of Lassa fever has been confirmed in the FCT and its\nenvirons, and out of the 12 cases reported since February [2009], 5\npatients have died.\n\nMeanwhile, in a presentation on Lassa fever during the monthly\nmeeting of the Abuja Chapter of the Guild, the National President, Dr\nCharles Cudjoe, called for more rapid diagnostic test centres for\nLassa fever. \"The Guild did a survey at the outbreak of this disease,\nand, disturbingly, we discovered that there was not enough Ribavirin.\nWe discovered that the drug that is in stock in some pharmaceutical\nstores would expire this month [March 2009]. That is a bit of a\nproblem, because we need to tackle this as quickly as possible. All\nhands must be on deck to import these drugs from the companies that\nmake them. Even if the epidemic does not expand, we should be able to\nhandle the few cases that come in,\" he said.\n\nThe News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) discovered that a pack of 45 tablets\nof Ribavirin 400 mg is sold for 115 pounds sterling [USD 167] in the\nUK, while 84 tablets of the same drug went for 274 pounds sterling\n[USD 398]. A survey had shown that Roche and Swipha are the 2\ncompanies that manufacture this drug. In Abuja, 45 tablets of\nRibavirin 400 mg went for Naira 25 000 [USD 169] for a stock that is\ndue to expire this month [March 2009], while the cost for the same\ndrug with a later expiration date is about Naira 120 000 [USD 807].\nCudjoe expressed reservation over the handling of the epidemic that\nwas 1st discovered in the town of Lassa in Borno.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Since January 2008, Lassa fever virus infection has affected more\nthan 390 people and been responsible for 55 deaths in Nigeria. Since\nFebruary 2009, there have been 12 additional cases and 5 deaths in\nthe proximity of the Federal Capital Territory. From these figures,\nit is difficult to predict the future course of the epidemic.\n\nRibavirin is an anti-viral drug indicated for severe respiratory\nsyncytial virus infections (individually), hepatitis C infection\n(used in conjunction with peginterferon alfa-2b) and other viral\ninfections. It has been used successfully in hospitals in the\ntreatment of Lassa fever virus infection. Ribavirin is a prodrug,\nwhich, when metabolized, resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this\nform, it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral\nreplication. How it exactly affects viral replication is unknown.\nMultiple mechanisms may be responsible for its actions. The primary\nobserved serious adverse side-effect of Ribavirin is hemolytic\nanemia. Ribavirin is also a teratogen in some animal species and thus\nposes a theoretical reproductive risk in humans, remaining a hazard\nas long as the drug is present, which can be as long as 6 months\nafter a course of the drug has ended (see:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribavirin>).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (06) 20090309.0981\nLassa fever - Nigeria (05) 20090308.0971\nLassa fever - Nigeria (04): control 20090306.0937\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03) 20090305.0913\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20090225.0788\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20090218.0669\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\n..........................................cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More than 51 million Nigerians\nare at risk, with the annual number of illnesses estimated at 3\nmillion and with the number of deaths estimated at about 58 330.\n\nThis disclosure came as the Guild of Medical Directors yesterday [18\nMar 2009] in Abuja demanded an adequate supply of Ribavirin (the\nantiviral drug for the treatment of Lassa fever) in the Federal\nCapital Territory (FCT) and its environs. Chief Medical Director of\nthe Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital, Irrua Edo State, Prof. George\nAkpede, made the disclosure yesterday on the occasion of the\ncommissioning of the Lassa Fever Diagnostic and Research Laboratory,\nInstitute of Lassa Fever Research and Control at the Irrua\nSpecialists Teaching Hospital, Irrua, Edo State. He said the Lassa\nfever epidemic was no longer limited to some states as it was thought\nbut had assumed virtually a country-wide dimension.\n\nThe outbreak of Lassa fever has been confirmed in the FCT and its\nenvirons, and out of the 12 cases reported since February [2009], 5\npatients have died.\n\nMeanwhile, in a presentation on Lassa fever during the monthly\nmeeting of the Abuja Chapter of the Guild, the National President, Dr\nCharles Cudjoe, called for more rapid diagnostic test centres for\nLassa fever. \"The Guild did a survey at the outbreak of this disease,\nand, disturbingly, we discovered that there was not enough Ribavirin.\nWe discovered that the drug that is in stock in some pharmaceutical\nstores would expire this month [March 2009]. That is a bit of a\nproblem, because we need to tackle this as quickly as possible. All\nhands must be on deck to import these drugs from the companies that\nmake them. Even if the epidemic does not expand, we should be able to\nhandle the few cases that come in,\" he said.\n\nThe News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) discovered that a pack of 45 tablets\nof Ribavirin 400 mg is sold for 115 pounds sterling [USD 167] in the\nUK, while 84 tablets of the same drug went for 274 pounds sterling\n[USD 398]. A survey had shown that Roche and Swipha are the 2\ncompanies that manufacture this drug. In Abuja, 45 tablets of\nRibavirin 400 mg went for Naira 25 000 [USD 169] for a stock that is\ndue to expire this month [March 2009], while the cost for the same\ndrug with a later expiration date is about Naira 120 000 [USD 807].\nCudjoe expressed reservation over the handling of the epidemic that\nwas 1st discovered in the town of Lassa in Borno.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Since January 2008, Lassa fever virus infection has affected more\nthan 390 people and been responsible for 55 deaths in Nigeria. Since\nFebruary 2009, there have been 12 additional cases and 5 deaths in\nthe proximity of the Federal Capital Territory. From these figures,\nit is difficult to predict the future course of the epidemic.\n\nRibavirin is an anti-viral drug indicated for severe respiratory\nsyncytial virus infections (individually), hepatitis C infection\n(used in conjunction with peginterferon alfa-2b) and other viral\ninfections. It has been used successfully in hospitals in the\ntreatment of Lassa fever virus infection. Ribavirin is a prodrug,\nwhich, when metabolized, resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this\nform, it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral\nreplication. How it exactly affects viral replication is unknown.\nMultiple mechanisms may be responsible for its actions. The primary\nobserved serious adverse side-effect of Ribavirin is hemolytic\nanemia. Ribavirin is also a teratogen in some animal species and thus\nposes a theoretical reproductive risk in humans, remaining a hazard\nas long as the drug is present, which can be as long as 6 months\nafter a course of the drug has ended (see:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribavirin>).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (06) 20090309.0981\nLassa fever - Nigeria (05) 20090308.0971\nLassa fever - Nigeria (04): control 20090306.0937\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03) 20090305.0913\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20090225.0788\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20090218.0669\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\n..........................................cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More than 51 million Nigerians\nare at risk, with the annual number of illnesses estimated at 3\nmillion and with the number of deaths estimated at about 58 330.\n\nThis disclosure came as the Guild of Medical Directors yesterday [18\nMar 2009] in Abuja demanded an adequate supply of Ribavirin (the\nantiviral drug for the treatment of Lassa fever) in the Federal\nCapital Territory (FCT) and its environs. Chief Medical Director of\nthe Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital, Irrua Edo State, Prof. George\nAkpede, made the disclosure yesterday on the occasion of the\ncommissioning of the Lassa Fever Diagnostic and Research Laboratory,\nInstitute of Lassa Fever Research and Control at the Irrua\nSpecialists Teaching Hospital, Irrua, Edo State. He said the Lassa\nfever epidemic was no longer limited to some states as it was thought\nbut had assumed virtually a country-wide dimension.\n\nThe outbreak of Lassa fever has been confirmed in the FCT and its\nenvirons, and out of the 12 cases reported since February [2009], 5\npatients have died.\n\nMeanwhile, in a presentation on Lassa fever during the monthly\nmeeting of the Abuja Chapter of the Guild, the National President, Dr\nCharles Cudjoe, called for more rapid diagnostic test centres for\nLassa fever. \"The Guild did a survey at the outbreak of this disease,\nand, disturbingly, we discovered that there was not enough Ribavirin.\nWe discovered that the drug that is in stock in some pharmaceutical\nstores would expire this month [March 2009]. That is a bit of a\nproblem, because we need to tackle this as quickly as possible. All\nhands must be on deck to import these drugs from the companies that\nmake them. Even if the epidemic does not expand, we should be able to\nhandle the few cases that come in,\" he said.\n\nThe News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) discovered that a pack of 45 tablets\nof Ribavirin 400 mg is sold for 115 pounds sterling [USD 167] in the\nUK, while 84 tablets of the same drug went for 274 pounds sterling\n[USD 398]. A survey had shown that Roche and Swipha are the 2\ncompanies that manufacture this drug. In Abuja, 45 tablets of\nRibavirin 400 mg went for Naira 25 000 [USD 169] for a stock that is\ndue to expire this month [March 2009], while the cost for the same\ndrug with a later expiration date is about Naira 120 000 [USD 807].\nCudjoe expressed reservation over the handling of the epidemic that\nwas 1st discovered in the town of Lassa in Borno.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Since January 2008, Lassa fever virus infection has affected more\nthan 390 people and been responsible for 55 deaths in Nigeria. Since\nFebruary 2009, there have been 12 additional cases and 5 deaths in\nthe proximity of the Federal Capital Territory. From these figures,\nit is difficult to predict the future course of the epidemic.\n\nRibavirin is an anti-viral drug indicated for severe respiratory\nsyncytial virus infections (individually), hepatitis C infection\n(used in conjunction with peginterferon alfa-2b) and other viral\ninfections. It has been used successfully in hospitals in the\ntreatment of Lassa fever virus infection. Ribavirin is a prodrug,\nwhich, when metabolized, resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this\nform, it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral\nreplication. How it exactly affects viral replication is unknown.\nMultiple mechanisms may be responsible for its actions. The primary\nobserved serious adverse side-effect of Ribavirin is hemolytic\nanemia. Ribavirin is also a teratogen in some animal species and thus\nposes a theoretical reproductive risk in humans, remaining a hazard\nas long as the drug is present, which can be as long as 6 months\nafter a course of the drug has ended (see:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribavirin>).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (06) 20090309.0981\nLassa fever - Nigeria (05) 20090308.0971\nLassa fever - Nigeria (04): control 20090306.0937\nLassa fever - Nigeria (03) 20090305.0913\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20090225.0788\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20090218.0669\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\n..........................................cp/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. UK ex Mali (02): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=164718", "date": "2009-02-18 12:00:49", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 16 Feb 2009\nSource: AllAfrica, This Day report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200902160188.html>\n\n\nNigeria: Lassa fever -- specialist expresses concern over spread\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nThe chief medical director of Irrua Specialist Hospital, Prof George\nAkpede, has expressed concern over the wide spread of Lassa fever in\nrecent times, disclosing that out of 229 suspected cases reported\nbetween January and December 2008, 30 people died.\n\nProf Akpede, who spoke at National Lassa Fever Stakeholders Forum at\nEkpoma [at the] weekend [14-15 Feb 2009] noted that there had been a\nmarked rise in the number of suspected and confirmed cases between\nDecember 2008 and January 2009 representing about 60 percent and 80\npercent increases respectively. He, however, disclosed that some\ndrastic measures were under way as the Irrua Specialist Teaching\nHospital had entered into partnerships with Behard-Notch Institute of\nTropical Medicine, Hamburg, Germany, and Harvard University, USA for\ncollaboration in Lassa fever research and control efforts. Part of\nthe collaboration, according to him, had resulted in the donation of\ndiagnostic facilities for the confirmation of the disease in the\nhospital without samples having to be sent out of the country any longer.\n\nIn his contribution, [the] member representing Esan Central/Esan\nWest/Igueben Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives,\nMr. Patrick Ikhariale, also expressed concern over the spread of the\nLassa fever epidemic nation-wide and called for urgent control\nmeasures at the national level. Ikhariale assured that he would draw\nthe attention of the National Assembly to the menace posed by the\ndisease to millions of Nigerians.\n\n[Byline: Adibe Emenyonu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease, whereby humans become infected\nfrom contact with infected animals. The animal reservoirs of Lassa\nvirus are rodents of the genus _Mastomys_, the \"multimammate rat.\"\nLassa virus-infected animals do not become ill, but they can shed the\nvirus in their urine and faeces. (A photograph of a multimammate rat\ncan be accessed at\n<http://i127.photobucket.com/albums/p145/hawthornrats/other%20pets/multis/DSCF4892.jpg>).\n\nIn humans Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4\nweeks duration that occurs in West Africa. The virus is a\nsingle-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family\n_Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea\n(Conakry), Liberia, Sierra Leone, and parts of Nigeria, but probably\nexists in other West African countries as well.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining\ncases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects\nseveral organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys.\nThe incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. It has\nbeen estimated that about 300 000 to 500 000 cases of Lassa fever and\n5000 deaths occur yearly across West Africa. The overall\ncase-fatality rate is 1 percent, and up to 15 percent among\nhospitalized patients.\n\nThe disease is especially severe late in pregnancy, with maternal\ndeath and/or fetal loss occurring in greater than 80 percent of cases\nduring the 3rd trimester.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to\nexcreta of infected _Mastomys_. Lassa virus may also be spread\nbetween humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces,\nor other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans.\nPerson-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical\nequipment, such as re-used needles.\n\nThe current increase in cases of Lassa fever in some parts of Nigeria\nmay by a consequence of increased abundance of the vector or some\nother factor resulting in increased contact between humans and\nrodents promoting the spread of the disease in the human population. - Mod.CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n-----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\nLassa Fever - South Africa ex Nigeria 20070222.0657\n2005\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20050303.0654\n2004\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20040214.0487\nLassa fever - Nigeria: RFI 20040213.0482\n2001\n----\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo) (02) 20010319.0552\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo): RFI 20010315.0524\n2000\n----\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (03) 20000424.0609\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (02) 20000405.0497\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria 20000404.0495\n...................................cp/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Part of\nthe collaboration, according to him, had resulted in the donation of\ndiagnostic facilities for the confirmation of the disease in the\nhospital without samples having to be sent out of the country any longer.\n\nIn his contribution, [the] member representing Esan Central/Esan\nWest/Igueben Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives,\nMr. Patrick Ikhariale, also expressed concern over the spread of the\nLassa fever epidemic nation-wide and called for urgent control\nmeasures at the national level. He, however, disclosed that some\ndrastic measures were under way as the Irrua Specialist Teaching\nHospital had entered into partnerships with Behard-Notch Institute of\nTropical Medicine, Hamburg, Germany, and Harvard University, USA for\ncollaboration in Lassa fever research and control efforts. Part of\nthe collaboration, according to him, had resulted in the donation of\ndiagnostic facilities for the confirmation of the disease in the\nhospital without samples having to be sent out of the country any longer.\n\nIn his contribution, [the] member representing Esan Central/Esan\nWest/Igueben Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives,\nMr. Patrick Ikhariale, also expressed concern over the spread of the\nLassa fever epidemic nation-wide and called for urgent control\nmeasures at the national level. Ikhariale assured that he would draw\nthe attention of the National Assembly to the menace posed by the\ndisease to millions of Nigerians.\n\n[Byline: Adibe Emenyonu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease, whereby humans become infected\nfrom contact with infected animals. The animal reservoirs of Lassa\nvirus are rodents of the genus _Mastomys_, the \"multimammate rat.\"\nLassa virus-infected animals do not become ill, but they can shed the\nvirus in their urine and faeces. (A photograph of a multimammate rat\ncan be accessed at\n<http://i127.photobucket.com/albums/p145/hawthornrats/other%20pets/multis/DSCF4892.jpg>).\n\nIn humans Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4\nweeks duration that occurs in West Africa. The virus is a\nsingle-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family\n_Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea\n(Conakry), Liberia, Sierra Leone, and parts of Nigeria, but probably\nexists in other West African countries as well.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining\ncases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects\nseveral organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys.\nThe incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. It has\nbeen estimated that about 300 000 to 500 000 cases of Lassa fever and\n5000 deaths occur yearly across West Africa. The overall\ncase-fatality rate is 1 percent, and up to 15 percent among\nhospitalized patients.\n\nThe disease is especially severe late in pregnancy, with maternal\ndeath and/or fetal loss occurring in greater than 80 percent of cases\nduring the 3rd trimester.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to\nexcreta of infected _Mastomys_. Lassa virus may also be spread\nbetween humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces,\nor other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans.\nPerson-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical\nequipment, such as re-used needles.\n\nThe current increase in cases of Lassa fever in some parts of Nigeria\nmay by a consequence of increased abundance of the vector or some\nother factor resulting in increased contact between humans and\nrodents promoting the spread of the disease in the human population. - Mod.CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n-----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\nLassa Fever - South Africa ex Nigeria 20070222.0657\n2005\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20050303.0654\n2004\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20040214.0487\nLassa fever - Nigeria: RFI 20040213.0482\n2001\n----\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo) (02) 20010319.0552\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo): RFI 20010315.0524\n2000\n----\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (03) 20000424.0609\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (02) 20000405.0497\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria 20000404.0495\n...................................cp/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Lassa virus may also be spread\nbetween humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces,\nor other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans.\nPerson-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical\nequipment, such as re-used needles.\n\nThe current increase in cases of Lassa fever in some parts of Nigeria\nmay by a consequence of increased abundance of the vector or some\nother factor resulting in increased contact between humans and\nrodents promoting the spread of the disease in the human population. - Mod.CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal 20090130.0414\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (02) 20090124.0308\nLassa fever - UK ex Nigeria 20090123.0296\n2008\n-----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (02) 20080611.1847\nLassa fever - Nigeria: (Ebonyi) 20080323.1100\n2007\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria 20071205.3925\nLassa Fever - South Africa ex Nigeria 20070222.0657\n2005\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20050303.0654\n2004\n----\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20040214.0487\nLassa fever - Nigeria: RFI 20040213.0482\n2001\n----\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo) (02) 20010319.0552\nLassa fever, suspected - Nigeria (Edo): RFI 20010315.0524\n2000\n----\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (03) 20000424.0609\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (02) 20000405.0497\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria 20000404.0495\n...................................cp/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mod.TY, edited]\n<http://www.panapress.com/freenewspor.asp?code=por006429&dte=19/04/2007>\n\nLassa fever, recently declared to be occurring in northern and\ncentral Liberia, has caused 5 deaths, announced a spokesman of the\nMinistry of Health, Karson Kollie, on Wednesday [18 Apr 2007]. Kollie\nstated that at least 13 people have been infected by this disease,\nwhich is transmitted by the saliva of rodents, including rats [by the\nexcrement and urine of the multimammate mouse, _Mastomys natalensis_\n- Mod.TY]. Kollie indicated that the registered cases of Lassa fever\nhave been concentrated in the localities of Bong, Lofa and Nimba.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-Port\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that sporadic cases of Lassa fever continue in these\nareas, although the numbers of cases in the earlier reports this year\n[2007] are not available, and it is unclear whether there has been an increase.\nA map of Liberia showing Lofa, Nimba and Bong counties can be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/liberia_pol_2004.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Liberia (02): confirmed 20070413.1235\nLassa Fever - Liberia: RFI 20070410.1210\n2006\n----\nLassa fever - Liberia (02) 20061001.2812\nLassa fever - Liberia: RFI 20060929.2783\n............................................ty/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Torres <torresjaime@cantv.net>\nSource: EFE Salud [translated from Spanish by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.efe.es/salud/principal.asp?opcion=14>\n\nBelgian health authorities issued a preventive call to the passengers arriving\nin Brussels from Sierra Leone on 11 Jul [2006], or who flew on the morning of\nthat day to Frankfurt, Germany. Information from Germany indicated that a\nLassa fever case traveled that route.\nBelgian health authorities were informed last night [21 Jul 2006] that a\nperson hospitalized in Germany arrived in Brussels that day [21 Jul 2006] in a\nBrussels Airlines flight coming from Freetown, [Sierra Leone], where [the\npassenger] contracted Lassa fever, a hemorrhagic viral fever, per the analysis\nthat was provided.\nThe patient, who arrived in Brussels a 03:35 GMT, took a flight to Frankfurt\nwith the same company at 04:30 GMT, according to the radio station Bel-RTL.\ufffd\nHealth authorities [Belgian?] who made the announcement concerning the case\nrequest that passengers on those 2 flights contact the Ambres University\nHospital.\nLassa fever, which takes its name from the region in Nigeria where the first\ncase appeared in 1969, is very contagious and can be fatal. Lassa fever virus\nis transmitted in blood, urine, saliva, and respiratory secretions, although\nthe patient did not manifest this [respiratory symptoms] during the trip from\nFreetown to Frankfurt, according to the communication.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fortunately, the risk of aerosolized Lassa fever virus transmission via the\nrespiratory route is extremely low.\nThere have been sporadic cases of rodent reservoir-to-human transmission in\nWest Africa. Human-to-human Lassa fever virus transmission has been mainly a\nhospital problem when medical staff, other patient care-givers, and persons\n(especially family members) in intimate contact with Lassa fever patients have\nbeen directly exposed to blood and other bodily fluids, usually in the absence\nof barrier nursing. Early in the initial Nigerian epidemic, a nurse infected\nand ill with Lassa fever virus traveled from Nigeria to New York by air\nwithout transmission of the virus to other passengers or the airline crew. In\nstudies conducted in the 1960s and 1970s, there was no evidence of Lassa fever\nvirus transmission to airline passengers traveling with confirmed Lassa fever\ncases (1). Similarly, in 2004, 19 passengers on a flight from London to\nNewark, New Jersey, USA, with a Lassa fever virus-infected man returning from\nLiberia, were considered at low risk of exposure, and none became infected\nwith the virus -- see ProMED ref. below. While awareness is indicated, care\nshould be taken not to engender fear among the passengers.\nReference:\n1. Galbraith NS, Berrie JRH, Forbes P, Young S. Public Health aspects of viral\nhaemorrhagic fevers in Britain. J R Soc Health 1978; 98: 152-60.\n- Mod.TY]\n[see also\n2005\n----\nLassa fever - West Africa: WHO Update 20050311.0721\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20050303.0654\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (Kenema) 20050212.0475\n2004\n----\nLassa fever, imported - USA (NJ) ex Liberia (02) 20040930.2700]\n..................ty/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Lassa fever virus\nis transmitted in blood, urine, saliva, and respiratory secretions, although\nthe patient did not manifest this [respiratory symptoms] during the trip from\nFreetown to Frankfurt, according to the communication.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fortunately, the risk of aerosolized Lassa fever virus transmission via the\nrespiratory route is extremely low.\nThere have been sporadic cases of rodent reservoir-to-human transmission in\nWest Africa. Human-to-human Lassa fever virus transmission has been mainly a\nhospital problem when medical staff, other patient care-givers, and persons\n(especially family members) in intimate contact with Lassa fever patients have\nbeen directly exposed to blood and other bodily fluids, usually in the absence\nof barrier nursing. Early in the initial Nigerian epidemic, a nurse infected\nand ill with Lassa fever virus traveled from Nigeria to New York by air\nwithout transmission of the virus to other passengers or the airline crew. In\nstudies conducted in the 1960s and 1970s, there was no evidence of Lassa fever\nvirus transmission to airline passengers traveling with confirmed Lassa fever\ncases (1). Similarly, in 2004, 19 passengers on a flight from London to\nNewark, New Jersey, USA, with a Lassa fever virus-infected man returning from\nLiberia, were considered at low risk of exposure, and none became infected\nwith the virus -- see ProMED ref. below. While awareness is indicated, care\nshould be taken not to engender fear among the passengers.\nReference:\n1. Galbraith NS, Berrie JRH, Forbes P, Young S. Public Health aspects of viral\nhaemorrhagic fevers in Britain. J R Soc Health 1978; 98: 152-60.\n- Mod.TY]\n[see also\n2005\n----\nLassa fever - West Africa: WHO Update 20050311.0721\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20050303.0654\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (Kenema) 20050212.0475\n2004\n----\nLassa fever, imported - USA (NJ) ex Liberia (02) 20040930.2700]\n..................ty/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Preliminary\nlaboratory testing performed by the WHO Collaborating Centers, the National\nInstitute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa has confirmed Lassa fever\ninfection. A team from WHO headquarters and the WHO Country Office is\nassessing the situation and the need to conduct further investigations,\nassisting patient management in the isolation units of Kenema hospital, and\nidentifying measures to control the outbreak.\n--\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\n[Lassa fever is a hemorrhagic fever caused by Lassa virus, a\nnegative-strand RNA virus with a bipartite genome belonging to the family\n_Arenaviridae_, that is endemic in parts of West Africa. Lassa virus\nbelongs to the old world group of arenaviruses. Like all arenaviruses these\nviruses cause persistent infections of rodents (_Mastomys_ sp. in the case\nof Lassa virus) usually without obvious signs of disease. Humans and other\nanimals are infected through contact with rodent excreta, particularly\nurine. Cases of Lassa fever are limited to West Africa and have been\nreported most frequently from Sierra Leone, and to a lesser extent from\nNigeria, Liberia, and Guinea. In endemic areas of rural West Africa\nsubclinical infection is common, but occasional outbreaks with high\nmortality rates have been recorded. There is also risk of transmission of\ndisease when unrecognized Lassa fever cases are imported into non-endemic\nregions for treatment of haemorrhagic disease. Kenema district is located\nin the south of Sierra Leone close to the border with Liberia. Further\ninformation on this outbreak in Kenema is awaited.- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20040214.0487\nLassa fever - Nigeria: RFI 20040213.0482\n2003\n----\nLassa fever, imported - UK ex Sierra Leone 20030210.0360\nLassa fever, imported - UK ex Sierra Leone (02) 20030211.0371\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone 20030409.0863\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (south & east) 20030404.0827\n2000\n----\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (03) 20000424.0609\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (02) 20000405.0497\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria 20000404.0495\nLassa fever: background 20000325.0429\n........................cp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Preliminary\nlaboratory testing performed by the WHO Collaborating Centers, the National\nInstitute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa has confirmed Lassa fever\ninfection. A team from WHO headquarters and the WHO Country Office is\nassessing the situation and the need to conduct further investigations,\nassisting patient management in the isolation units of Kenema hospital, and\nidentifying measures to control the outbreak.\n--\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\n[Lassa fever is a hemorrhagic fever caused by Lassa virus, a\nnegative-strand RNA virus with a bipartite genome belonging to the family\n_Arenaviridae_, that is endemic in parts of West Africa. Lassa virus\nbelongs to the old world group of arenaviruses. Like all arenaviruses these\nviruses cause persistent infections of rodents (_Mastomys_ sp. in the case\nof Lassa virus) usually without obvious signs of disease. Humans and other\nanimals are infected through contact with rodent excreta, particularly\nurine. Cases of Lassa fever are limited to West Africa and have been\nreported most frequently from Sierra Leone, and to a lesser extent from\nNigeria, Liberia, and Guinea. In endemic areas of rural West Africa\nsubclinical infection is common, but occasional outbreaks with high\nmortality rates have been recorded. There is also risk of transmission of\ndisease when unrecognized Lassa fever cases are imported into non-endemic\nregions for treatment of haemorrhagic disease. Kenema district is located\nin the south of Sierra Leone close to the border with Liberia. Further\ninformation on this outbreak in Kenema is awaited.- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nLassa fever - Nigeria (Edo) 20040214.0487\nLassa fever - Nigeria: RFI 20040213.0482\n2003\n----\nLassa fever, imported - UK ex Sierra Leone 20030210.0360\nLassa fever, imported - UK ex Sierra Leone (02) 20030211.0371\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone 20030409.0863\nLassa fever - Sierra Leone (south & east) 20030404.0827\n2000\n----\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (03) 20000424.0609\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria (02) 20000405.0497\nLassa fever - Germany ex Nigeria 20000404.0495\nLassa fever: background 20000325.0429\n........................cp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. McCormick <JxSMCCORMK@aol.com>\n\nA comment\n---------------------------------\nLassa fever is endemic in Nigeria. Epidemics when they occur are\nsuperimposed upon a background of continuing disease. December to April are\nthe peak months, but it occurs through the year. Any other interpretation\nis due to observation errors (failure to observe, report, etc.). So what's\nnew?\nIt would be good to have more solid data, but this has been difficult to\ncollect. Our studies (Tomori, Nasidi, McCormick, Fisher-Hoch) in 1989\nremain, regrettably, the most recent published surveys reporting objective\ndata gathered in the field.\n--\nDr. J.B. Nasidi\" <nasidia@hotmail.com> reported that\nmembers of his staff went out at the end of the outbreak, but could not\nperform detailed investigations. They worked mostly in one medical centre,\nthus missing many cases. They also could not perform any house-to-house\nsurvey. After an outbreak\ninvestigation and contact tracing, 77 contacts, including family members\nand hospital workers, are being followed with recording of body\ntemperature twice daily and monitoring for symptoms. So far two nurses\nhave developed fever, in both cases found to be due to malaria.\nSurveillance of contacts will continue for 21 days (the upper limit of\nthe incubation period). Lassa fever guidelines for prevention and case\nmanagement developed by WHO and the NGO MERLIN have been widely\ndistributed.\nContrary to newspaper reports, there have been no confirmed cases in IDP\ncamps. Because the rat of genus _Mastomys_, the animal vector, is not\nindigenous to Freetown, it is unlikely that the disease will become\nestablished here.\nAny questions are welcome.\n--\nW. After an outbreak\ninvestigation and contact tracing, 77 contacts, including family members\nand hospital workers, are being followed with recording of body\ntemperature twice daily and monitoring for symptoms. So far two nurses\nhave developed fever, in both cases found to be due to malaria.\nSurveillance of contacts will continue for 21 days (the upper limit of\nthe incubation period). Lassa fever guidelines for prevention and case\nmanagement developed by WHO and the NGO MERLIN have been widely\ndistributed.\nContrary to newspaper reports, there have been no confirmed cases in IDP\ncamps. Because the rat of genus _Mastomys_, the animal vector, is not\nindigenous to Freetown, it is unlikely that the disease will become\nestablished here.\nAny questions are welcome.\n--\nW. Aldis, MD\nCountry Representative\nWorld Health Organization,\nSierra Leone\n<who@sierratel.sl>\n[The information from Dr. Aldis provides welcome authoritative\nclarification of the current situation with regard to Lassa fever in\nFreetown. The deceased was identified by the\nhospital authorities as a 37-year male who had apparently arrived in\nGermany on a Ghana Airways flight. The Ministry of Health, Ghana assured\nthe Ghanaian Embassy that no case of Lassa fever had been reported in Ghana\nand thus the patient could not have been infected in Ghana. The Ministry\nof Health recommended that the origin of the patient be verified since his\nname did not sound Ghanaian nor did his supposed arrival via Ghana Airways\nmean that he had recently stayed in Ghana.\nOn 26 September the Mainz hospital authorities called a press conference\nand announced that tests conducted at the Tropical Disease Institute at the\nBernhard Nocht Institute, Hamburg had dismissed Lassa fever as the cause of\ndeath of the man. The press release was issued to assure Ghanaians and all\nvisitors to Ghana that Lassa fever has never been detected in Ghana. Ever\nsince the detection of the cases of Lassa fever in Nigeria, Ghanaian\nclinicians have been particular about examining cases of fever with\nhaemorrhagic tendencies thoroughly. In addition the Noguchi Memorial\nInstitute for Medical Research at the University of Ghana has often been\ncalled upon to support the national laboratory network in this work. The deceased was identified by the\nhospital authorities as a 37-year male who had apparently arrived in\nGermany on a Ghana Airways flight. The Ministry of Health, Ghana assured\nthe Ghanaian Embassy that no case of Lassa fever had been reported in Ghana\nand thus the patient could not have been infected in Ghana. The Ministry\nof Health recommended that the origin of the patient be verified since his\nname did not sound Ghanaian nor did his supposed arrival via Ghana Airways\nmean that he had recently stayed in Ghana.\nOn 26 September the Mainz hospital authorities called a press conference\nand announced that tests conducted at the Tropical Disease Institute at the\nBernhard Nocht Institute, Hamburg had dismissed Lassa fever as the cause of\ndeath of the man. The press release was issued to assure Ghanaians and all\nvisitors to Ghana that Lassa fever has never been detected in Ghana. Ever\nsince the detection of the cases of Lassa fever in Nigeria, Ghanaian\nclinicians have been particular about examining cases of fever with\nhaemorrhagic tendencies thoroughly. In addition the Noguchi Memorial\nInstitute for Medical Research at the University of Ghana has often been\ncalled upon to support the national laboratory network in this work. The\nMinistry of Health is confident that their disease surveillance system is\nvery active and should a case of Lassa fever or any other unusual disease\nappear in the country it will be detected and contained.\n--\nDr James Chin\nCDCP-mail\n[We thank the Ghanaian authorities for providing this information and the\nreassurance that Lassa fever is not occurring in Ghana. - Mod.CHC\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The number of cases increased from 45\nwith 7 deaths (15.6%) in January to 75 cases and 9 deaths (12.0%) in\nFebruary, and 147 cases with 20 deaths (13.4%) in March but decreased to 86\ncases with 7 deaths (8.1%) in April. The resumption of civil unrest in\nKenema in late April and the brief closure of the Kenema hospital may have\nadversely affected reporting. During 1996, a total of 470 cases with 110\ndeaths (23.4%) were reported. While the majority of cases sought medical\ncare in Kenema four cases were identified in Freetown. Initially, cases\nseeking medical care in Freetown were transported to Kenema but an isolation\nward is now being established in Freetown using health staff trained at the\nLassa fever isolation ward in Kenema to ensure prompt management of suspect\ncases.\nThe Ministry of Health and Sanitation together with WHO and MERLIN is\nplanning activities to prevent the spread of the disease and improve\nmanagement of suspect cases. Key district health personnel will be included\nin a nation-wide training programme on Lassa fever control that is planned\nfor later in the year. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is studying a\nplan for rodent control. Treatment with ribavirin was resumed in mid-April\nwith the arrival of new supplies of the drug after the stock was depleted in\nFebruary. Ribavirin will be distributed to other areas where health\npersonnel are familiar with administration of this drug for the treatment of\nLassa fever. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is also establishing a\nnational Lassa fever control programme with a programme manager based in\nKenema.\n_________________________________\nNOTES CONCERNING THIS SERVICE:\nThe Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) serves as an\nessential instrument for the rapid and accurate\ndissemination of epidemiological information on cases and\noutbreaks of diseases under the International Health\nRegulations, other communicable diseases of public health\nimportance, including the newly emerging or re-emerging\ninfections, non-communicable diseases and other health\nproblems. The WER is distributed every Friday in a\nbilingual English/French edition. The electronic edition is\nfree of charge and can be obtained through FTP: ftp.who.ch,\nuser name should be \"anonymous\", password should be your\ne.mail address. The WER issues are in the subdirectory\n/pub/wer, or WWW: http://www.who.ch/wer/wer_home.htm\nAny queries on subscription to the printed edition should be\naddressed to: World Health Organization, Distribution and\nSales, 20 Avenue Appia, CH-1211 Geneva 27, Fax: (+4122) 791\n48 57\nIssues of the WER are in AdobeTM AcrobatTM portable document\nformat (.pdf). The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is also establishing a\nnational Lassa fever control programme with a programme manager based in\nKenema.\n_________________________________\nNOTES CONCERNING THIS SERVICE:\nThe Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) serves as an\nessential instrument for the rapid and accurate\ndissemination of epidemiological information on cases and\noutbreaks of diseases under the International Health\nRegulations, other communicable diseases of public health\nimportance, including the newly emerging or re-emerging\ninfections, non-communicable diseases and other health\nproblems. The number of cases increased from 45\nwith 7 deaths (15.6%) in January to 75 cases and 9 deaths (12.0%) in\nFebruary, and 147 cases with 20 deaths (13.4%) in March but decreased to 86\ncases with 7 deaths (8.1%) in April. The resumption of civil unrest in\nKenema in late April and the brief closure of the Kenema hospital may have\nadversely affected reporting. During 1996, a total of 470 cases with 110\ndeaths (23.4%) were reported. While the majority of cases sought medical\ncare in Kenema four cases were identified in Freetown. Initially, cases\nseeking medical care in Freetown were transported to Kenema but an isolation\nward is now being established in Freetown using health staff trained at the\nLassa fever isolation ward in Kenema to ensure prompt management of suspect\ncases.\nThe Ministry of Health and Sanitation together with WHO and MERLIN is\nplanning activities to prevent the spread of the disease and improve\nmanagement of suspect cases. Key district health personnel will be included\nin a nation-wide training programme on Lassa fever control that is planned\nfor later in the year. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is studying a\nplan for rodent control. Treatment with ribavirin was resumed in mid-April\nwith the arrival of new supplies of the drug after the stock was depleted in\nFebruary. Ribavirin will be distributed to other areas where health\npersonnel are familiar with administration of this drug for the treatment of\nLassa fever. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is also establishing a\nnational Lassa fever control programme with a programme manager based in\nKenema.\n_________________________________\nNOTES CONCERNING THIS SERVICE:\nThe Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) serves as an\nessential instrument for the rapid and accurate\ndissemination of epidemiological information on cases and\noutbreaks of diseases under the International Health\nRegulations, other communicable diseases of public health\nimportance, including the newly emerging or re-emerging\ninfections, non-communicable diseases and other health\nproblems. Simms <TES@A1.cdrh.fda.gov>\nFound the following while reading an internet healthcare news listing.\n\n<http://www.fyionline.com/infoMCI/newsletter/HEALTH-MCI.html>\n\nLassa fever has killed nine people in eastern Sierra Leone. Physicians say\nthe outbreak is the worst on record there. Dr. Simon Mardel of the British\naid agency Medical Emergency Relief International (MERLIN) told Reuters by\ntelephone from Kenema that 74 sufferers had been admitted to hospital there\nin February -- the highest number on record.\n\"This is clearly the worst (Lassa) epidemic -- and I mean epidemic in the\nreal sense -- in Sierra Leone to date. There has definitely been a rapid\ndeterioration recently,\" Mardel said.\nThe Lassa fever ward opened May, 1996 but there were 10 cases in February\n199[7] and the annual average is usually around 35.\nLassa fever, spread by rat urine and feces or between humans, causes fever,\nminor hemorrhaging, vomiting, chest pains and low blood pressure. It killed\nabout one in four people infected in 1996.\nThe disease is endemic in eastern Sierra Leone but Mardel blamed the surge on\npoverty caused by almost five years of civil war and a rise in the rat\npopulation.\n\"People don't have the mechanisms to destroy the rats or protect their food.\nThe human element of transmission has also increased because of overcrowding\nand, as a result of the war, there is less access to health care,\" he said.\nThe only known cure, Ribavirin, a costly drug previously donated by the\nUnited States is no longer produced there. \"We have only one week's supply\nleft,\" Mardel said. \"We are now looking for another source, maybe China or\nRussia.\"\n---\nThomas Simms\nBiologist, Microbiology Branch\nDCLD, ODE, CDRH, FDA, HHS\nTEL: (301) 594-2096\nFAX: (301) 594-5941\ne-mail: <tes@fdadr.cdrh.fda.gov>\n...........................................................................chc\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Dr. Simon Mardel of the British\naid agency Medical Emergency Relief International (MERLIN) told Reuters by\ntelephone from Kenema that 74 sufferers had been admitted to hospital there\nin February -- the highest number on record.\n\"This is clearly the worst (Lassa) epidemic -- and I mean epidemic in the\nreal sense -- in Sierra Leone to date. It killed\nabout one in four people infected in 1996.\nThe disease is endemic in eastern Sierra Leone but Mardel blamed the surge on\npoverty caused by almost five years of civil war and a rise in the rat\npopulation.\n\"People don't have the mechanisms to destroy the rats or protect their food.\nThe human element of transmission has also increased because of overcrowding\nand, as a result of the war, there is less access to health care,\" he said.\nThe only known cure, Ribavirin, a costly drug previously donated by the\nUnited States is no longer produced there. \"We have only one week's supply\nleft,\" Mardel said. \"We are now looking for another source, maybe China or\nRussia.\"\n---\nThomas Simms\nBiologist, Microbiology Branch\nDCLD, ODE, CDRH, FDA, HHS\nTEL: (301) 594-2096\nFAX: (301) 594-5941\ne-mail: <tes@fdadr.cdrh.fda.gov>\n...........................................................................chc\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A demonstration of barrier\nnursing techniqueswas also given.\n\nThe conclusion of the WHO support mission is that a major epidemic\nof Lassa Fever has occurred in Kailahun and Kenema Districts and is\ncontinuing as unusually large numbers of severely ill patients are\nstill being admitted to hospital, with a large number of deaths\nstill occurring.\n\nA total of 167 cases and 60 deaths have been recorded during the\nperiod January to 28 May 1996.\n\n........................................................................MHJ\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
